questions.text: A young female with a history of renal calculi complains of bone pain and abdominal cramps. On investigation, multiple fractures were discovered and serum calcium and PTH was raised. Phosphate levels were decreased. What is the most common cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given history of renal stones, bone pain, and abdominal cramps with multiple fractures is highly suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma arising sporadically.

It is associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and mutations in both copies of the MEN1 gene.

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types.

Primary hyperparathyroidism Secondary hyperparathyroidism Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

An autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

 Compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia Persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after the cause of prolonged hypocalcemia is corrected
Parathyroid  adenoma or hyperplasia Seen in chronic renal failure Seen after renal transplant.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common endocrine disorders, and it is an important cause of hypercalcemia. It also has reduced phosphate levels.

The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarized as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.”

Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumors. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: In the given image, the perineal membrane is denoted by:
questions.solution:
In the given image of a median sagittal section of a male perineum, the perineal membrane is denoted by the arrow marked as C.

The perineal membrane divides the urogenital triangle into:

  • A deep perineal space lying above it
  • A superficial perineal space lying below it

It has a distinct dorsal and a ventral portion, which are closely connected with Levator ani.
The dorsal portion is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall by its attachment to the ischiopubic ramus. The ventral portion, on the other hand, is contiguous with the structures supporting urethra.

The marked membranes in the given image are as follows:

questions.text: Estrogen β receptors are found in which of the following organs?
questions.solution:
Estrogen β receptors are found in the prostate.

Principal types of nuclear estrogen receptors

  • Estrogen receptor α (ERα) encoded by a gene on chromo­some 6
    • ERα is found primarily in the uterus, kidneys, liver, and heart.
  • Estrogen receptor β (ERβ), encoded by a gene on chromosome 14. 
    • ERβ is found in the ovaries, prostate, lungs, gastrointestinal tract, hemopoietic system, and central nervous system (CNS).

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast-enhanced MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to the excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. This syndrome is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. The excess serotonin produced is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA.  

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: What does fetal position refer to?

choices.text: Part of presentation which lies over the internal os
Relation of different parts of fetus to one another
Relation of the denominator to different quadrants of the pelvis
Part of fetus lying in the lower segment of uterus

questions.solution:
Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

Definition of various terminologies used for fetus in-utero:

Term: Definition:
Lie Relationship of the long axis of fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
Presentation Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
Presenting part

Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os
Attitude

The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
Denominator

An arbitrary bony fixed point on the presenting part which comes in relation with the various quadrants of the maternal pelvis
Position

Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis
Engagement

When the biparietal diameter has passed the plane of the pelvic brim, the head is said to be engaged.

questions.text: The drug which does not reduce the size of fibroid is ______
questions.solution:
Misoprostol does not help to reduce the size of the fibroid.

Medical therapy for fibroids includes mifepristone, GnRH analogs, Aromatase inhibitors.

Drugs to reduce the size of the fibroid:

  • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone/RU-486
  • Danazol (Usually not used due to androgenic side effects)
  • GnRH
    • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, busereli
    • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix
  • Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system
  • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM’s) – Asoprisnil

questions.text: All of the following are associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Sturge–Weber syndrome is not associated with hemangiosarcoma.

Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve are associated with the Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome shows the following features:

  • Facial port-wine nevi
  • Ipsilateral venous angiomas in the cortical leptomeninges
  • Mental retardation
  • Seizures, hemiplegia
  • Skull radio-opacities

Images show port-wine stain and tram-track calcification associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with burns to 45% of the body surface area for which she is started on antibiotics, IV fluids, NSAIDs and opioids, and wound care. 2 days later, she develops abdominal pain and vomiting. Endoscopy reveals multiple shallow erosions in the stomach and duodenum. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely for the ulcers in this patient?
questions.solution:
Reduced blood flow is the most likely cause of ulcers in this patient.

This patients clinical features are suggestive of Curlings ulcers. Curling ulcers are associated with severe burns or trauma. Curling ulcers occur as multiple shallow erosions in the stomach and proximal duodenum. Systemic hypotension or reduced blood flow caused by stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction results in gastric mucosal injury.

Other options:

Option B: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

Option C: Bacterial infection with Helicobacter pylori causes a type b gastritis which is predominantly in the gastric antrum.

Option D: NSAIDs block the function of cyclooxygenase 1(COX1) resulting in reduced prostaglandin synthesis. Prostaglandin synthesis is important for gastric mucus production which is protective against the gastric acid.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient underwent normal vaginal delivery. 1 hour postpartum, you notice blood loss from her genital tract. The amount of blood loss to consider as postpartum hemorrhage will be:
questions.solution:
Loss of 500ml of blood or more after completion of the third stage of labor in vaginal delivery is considered as PPH. 1000 ml blood loss from genital tract is considered PPH after a C section.  

Recent Update :

PPH is classically defined by the volume of blood loss. But this definition will soon become obsolete due to its unreliability as the bleeding may not be visible externally, or blood in collection devices may be mixed with the amniotic fluid.

In 2017, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists revised their definition of PPH to

  • Cumulative blood loss of ≥1000 mL or
  • Bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours of the birth process (regardless of the route of delivery)

Constructed drapes and transfusion rates are two methods of assessing blood loss in the postpartum period.

questions.text: Peg cells are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Peg cells are seen in a fallopian tube.

A peg cell is a non-ciliated epithelial cell within the fallopian tube. These cells are also known as intercalated or intercalary cells.

questions.text: Which of the following reactions occurs most frequently in patients undergoing blood transfusions?
questions.solution:
Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR) is the most frequently occurring transfusion reaction.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Coomb’s test positive

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the medicine OPD with cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture done on the culture media is shown below. What is the usual method of sterilization used for this medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat-labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is Loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of Saint's triad?
questions.solution:
Saint's triad includes cholelithiasis.

Saint's triad includes the following:

  • Hiatus Hernia
  • Cholelithiasis (gall stones)
  • Diverticulosis of the colon

Other options :

  • Choledocholithiasis indicates the presence of a gallstone in the common bile duct.
  • Cholangitis indicates inflammation of the bile duct system.
  • Cholecystitis indicates inflammation of the gallbladder.

questions.text: A patient with Multiple Myeloma has elevated serum M protein component but dipstick for urine protein is negative. Which of the following class of immunoglobulins constitute a major part in this component?
questions.solution:
Serum M component is most likely to constitute IgG in major quantities.

The serum M component is IgG in 53% of patients, IgA in 25%, and IgD in 1%.

The "M" in M-component stands for "Monoclonal".

Serum Ig M is elevated in Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia (lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma).

Urine dipstick examinations primarily detect albumin. A 24-h urine protein quantitation and urine electrophoresis provide an estimate of total protein excretion, as well as the proportion of urine protein that is albumin versus monoclonal free light chains (M-protein).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years back, he was started on ACE inhibitors initially but takes it irregularly. His blood pressure readings have not been monitored since. His current Blood pressure readings are 160/94 mmHg. This case will fall under ____ in the given image below.
questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves. The given scenario describes a patient that is inadequately treated. Therefore, it would fall under the cases depicted as 8 in the image.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: Which of the following is not a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Apraxia is not a fundamental symptom of schizophrenia.

Eugene bleular has mentioned the fundamental symptoms of schizophrenia and they are known as the 4 A’s of schizophrenia.

They include:

  • Autism- Social withdrawal with delusions and hallucination.
  • Ambivalence- Presence of two opposite feelings at the same time.
  • Association disturbances- Mainly there is loosening of association, therefore, the person keeps jumping from one topic to another and doesn't remain consistent.
  • Affect problems- There is affective flattening or inappropriate affect.

questions.text: A patient with moderate COVID-19 was started on a long-acting glucocorticoid. Which of the following drugs could it be?
questions.solution:
Dexamethasone is the longest acting glucocorticoid. Its t1/2 is >36 hours.

Related Pearl: Classification of Glucocorticoids

Short-acting (t1/2 < 12 hours)

  • Hydrocortisone

Intermediate-acting (t1/2 of 12-36 hours)

  • Prednisolone
  • Methylprednisolone
  • Triamcinolone
  • Deflazacort

Long-acting (t1/2 > 36 hours)

  • Dexamethasone
  • Betamethasone

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the Intensified Mission Indradhanush Scheme?

choices.text: A total of 12 vaccines are included in this scheme.
Children and pregnant women benefit from this.
4 rounds of immunization are held for 7 days in each month.
Yellow fever and typhoid vaccine were added newly.

questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine and yellow fever vaccine are not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days in each month (from the 7th-13th of each month):

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

This is a potential question under recent updates in PSM. 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It was launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

questions.text: Identify the type of isomerism shown by the 2 molecules represented in the below image.
questions.solution:
In the above image, D-glucose and D-mannose differ in the position of –OH group in the second carbon atom. Hence, they are epimers.

Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.

Examples for epimers of glucose:

  • Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
  • Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: A young male presented with white growth over the cornea as shown in the image. Following complete ophthalmic examination, the excision of growth was done. In order to prevent recurrent growth, various techniques have been followed postoperatively. Which of the following techniques is associated with late scleral necrosis?
questions.solution:
In the given image we can see a triangular/wing-shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea suggestive of Pterygium. Beta-radiation applied postoperatively to the pterygium base was followed to prevent recurrence, but it is associated with late scleral necrosis.

A pterygium is best left alone unless it is progressing towards the pupillary area, causes excessive astigmatism, causes restriction of ocular motility or is disfiguring. The recurrence rates after simple excision are very high.

To prevent recurrance:

  • Beta-radiation applied postoperatively to the pterygium base was popular for many years, but is associated with late scleral necrosis.
  • Currently, the most widely used techniques are conjunctival autografting, amniotic membrane transplantation, and mitomycin-C application either preoperatively or postoperatively (can be applied intraoperatively also).

questions.text: What does the ultrasonography transducer contain?
questions.solution: Lead zirconate titanate (PZT) is the most widely used material in the ultrasound transducers/probes. It has replaced the previously used barium titanate.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient with renal failure has missed a round of dialysis. He complains of lethargy, anorexia, and vomiting. What is the probable acid-base disorder that we can expect in him?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis

questions.solution:
In renal failure, there is a loss of kidney function due to the damage affecting glomeruli and tubules. This leads to a high anion gap  metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan should be _______.
questions.solution:
Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. 

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a specimen from a patient with amyloidosis. When amyloid is stained with Congo red and visualized under ordinary light, which color does it acquire?
questions.solution:
When amyloid is stained with Congo red and is visualized under ordinary light, it shows red colour.

Amyloidosis results from the abnormal folding of proteins, which become insoluble, get aggregated, and are deposited as fibrils in extracellular tissues. Normally, misfolded proteins are degraded. Amyloid may be systemic (generalized), involving several organ systems, or it may be localized to a single organ.

The histologic diagnosis of amyloid is based almost entirely on its staining characteristics:

1. Light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin stain: Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

2. Congo red stain: 

  • Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to tissue deposits.
  • Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.

Images below show amyloid stained with congo red stain, under ordinary light, and under polarised light respectively

3. Electron microscopy: All types of amyloid are seen as continuous, nonbranching, nonoriented, thin fibrils

4. X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy: Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation of amyloid is seen. This conformation is actually responsible for the Congo red staining and birefringence of amyloid.

Related Pearl: Appearance of Amyloid

Methods Appearance
On light microscopy and standard tissue stains (H&E)  Amorphous eosinophilic extracellular substance 
Congo red stain on ordinary light    Pink or red colour to tissue deposits 
Congo red stain on polarizing microscopy   Apple-green birefringence 
Fluorescent stains (thioflavin T and S)    Yellow colour under UV light 
Electron microscopy  Nonbranching fibrils of indefinite length and a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm. 
X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy  Characteristic cross β pleated sheet conformation 

H&E: Hematoxylin and eosin

questions.text: A 40-year-old male was diagnosed with metastatic urothelial cancer and was started on a drug that enhances antitumor activity by blocking negative regulators of T cell function. All of the following drugs act through this mechanism except _________
questions.solution:
Dupilumab does not enhance antitumor activity by blocking negative regulators of T cell function. It is indicated in moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis. 

Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody against the alpha subunit of the IL-4 receptor. 

Immune checkpoint inhibitors inhibit proteins that help the cancer cells to keep immune responses in check. When these proteins are blocked, the brake on the immune system is released and T cells are able to kill cancer cells more efficiently.PDL1 inhibitors is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It is an antagonist of PD-L1 which is a protein-ligand that is present on antigen-presenting cells, T cells, B cells, and some cancer cells. These drugs  enhance antitumor activity by blocking negative regulators of T cell function

PD-L1 inhibitors are:

  • Atezolizumab
  • Avelumab
  • Durvalumab

All 3 approved for use in metastatic urothelial cancer while avelumab also for  Merkel cell cancer, and Atezolimumab also for NSCLC.

questions.text: A 4-day-old infant who was delivered at home is brought to the pediatrician for a routine checkup. The infant has a noticeable small mandible and cleft palate. A CT scan reveals hypoplasia of the mandible and a defect in the ​middle ear cavity and tympanic membrane. A developmental defect of which of the following pharyngeal arches is most likely?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of first arch syndrome due to the defect in the development of the first pharyngeal arch.

The derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch are:

Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences - 

  • Mandibular prominence (ventral)
    • Meckel's cartilage: Malleus, incus, anterior malleolar ligament, the spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular ligament. 
    • Mesenchyme: In the jaw region, it surrounds the Meckel's cartilage and undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible
  • Maxillary prominence (dorsal)
    • Mesenchyme:  Maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone are formed by membranous ossification

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives:

  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity

Muscular derivatives:

  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor veli palaitini
  • Muscles of mastication
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Mylohyoid

Vascular derivatives:

  • Maxillary artery

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery

  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus

  • Stylohyoid ligament

questions.text: Which of the following statement about the quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system is false?

choices.text: Score of 2 suggests potentially life threatening sepsis
Systolic blood pressure  ≤100 mmHg is one of its parameters
Respiratory rates ≥22/min is one of its parameters
It relies on laboratory and imaging findings

questions.solution:
The statement that the quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system relies on laboratory and imaging findings is false.

qSOFA is a screening and monitoring tool for patients with suspected sepsis. The qSOFA suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the following parameters are met.

  • Systolic blood pressure ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥22 breaths per min
  • Altered mental status (Glasgow coma scale <15)

It assigns one point for each. A score >2 is associated with a significant risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

Related Pearl: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine
Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

Creatinine (μmol/L) or urine output

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).

 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: A patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma is posted for surgery. He is nearly 6.5 ft tall, with a slender build and elongated digits. What is the screening test that should be done pre-operatively?
questions.solution:
This patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma and features of marfanoid habitus (very tall patient with long, slender fingers and toes) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines.

Pheochromocytoma, if present, should be treated first, and then MTC is to be treated next.

A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation). In case of familial medullary thyroid carcinoma, stimulation with pentagastrin increases the release of calcitonin. This can be used for the screening of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as:

  • Familial MTC
  • MEN 2A
  • MEN 2B

Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.

Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: An 18-year-old male needed frequent correction of the power of his glasses. He was diagnosed to have keratoconus. The following image shows the results of one of the investigations done to him. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution:
The investigation shown in the image is corneal topography.

Corneal topography is a method of imaging the cornea by projecting a series of concentric rings of light on the anterior surface. The reflected light is then analyzed using a computer software to produce a detailed surface map.

Uses:

  • Detection of corneal ectasia, mainly keratoconus
  • To measure corneal thickness
  • Screening for corneal ectasia is especially important prior to refractive surgery.
  • Sometimes prior to contact lens fitting.

questions.text: A 60-year-old singer visited ENT surgeon with the complaints of change of voice for the past few months. After a thorough examination, the doctor explained the reason for voice change is the laxity of the vocal cord due to the aging process. What type of thyroplasty can be performed in this person to improve his voice?
questions.solution:
Type 4 thyroplasty is performed to improve the voice in the above clinical scenario.

Type IV thyroplasty is used to lengthen (tighten) the vocal cord and elevate the pitch. It is used when vocal cord is lax and bowing due to aging process or trauma.

It is used to convert the male character of voice to female and has been used in gender transformation.

Thyroplasty is a phonosurgical technique which aims to improve the voice by altering the thyroid cartilage of the larynx (the voice box), which houses the vocal cords in order to change the position or the length of the vocal cords.

There are four different types of thyroplasty procedures described by Isshiki:

  • Type I: Medialization of vocal cord
  • Type II: Lateralization of vocal cord
  • Type III: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
  • Type IV: Lengthening or tightening of the vocal cord

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD presented with worsening dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pedal edema was present. An ECG was done and lead II showed the following pattern. Which of the following is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called P pulmonale and it is seen in cases of right atrial enlargement. The patient is showing features of heart failure possibly as a consequence of dysfunction caused by the overload. 

Signs of heart failure in this patient:

  • Bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities (systemic congestion)
  • Worsening dyspnea due to increased PCWP causing pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary edema (pulmonary congestion)

The features of P pulmonale include:

  • The amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II
  • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1

questions.text: A neonate was brought to the emergency room with lethargy and failure to thrive. A microscopic image of his hair strand is shown below. Which of the given enzymes may be deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows trichorrhexis nodosa and longitudinal breaks and is seen in argininosuccinic aciduria. This occurs due to a defect in the enzyme argininosuccinate lyase.

Trichorrhexis nodosa is a defect in the hair shaft characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. It can also be caused by other disorders such as hypothyroidism, iron deficiency and Menkes' kinky hair syndrome

questions.text: A resident while explaining about EEG to students asks one of them to volunteer and he records the EEG after advising him to rest for some time with closed eyes. What will be the frequency of  EEG waves observed in this person?
questions.solution:
Alpha waves on EEG are seen resting adult with eyes closed. Therefore the frequency of alpha waves observed in given clinical scenario is in the range of 8-13 Hz.

Various EEG waves and their frequency are,

EEG waves Frequency Seen in
Alpha 8–13 Hz Resting adult with eyes closed, arousable state of sedation
Beta 13-30 Hz Concentrating individuals, under anesthesia during initial stages
Theta 4–7 Hz Sleeping individuals and during anesthesia maintenance
Delta 0.5–4 Hz Brain injury, deep sleep, and anesthesia maintenance
Iso electric   Anesthesia induced coma, profound hypothermia

questions.text: Which of the following drugs was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the management of heavy menstrual bleeding associated with uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) in premenopausal women?
questions.solution:
Oriahnn (an estrogen and progestin combination product consisting of elagolix, estradiol, and norethindrone acetate) capsules, co-packaged for oral use, for the management of heavy menstrual bleeding associated with uterine leiomyomas (fibroids) in premenopausal women.

Fibroids are benign (non-cancerous) muscle tumours of the uterus that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, pain, bowel or bladder problems, and infertility. Some women may not experience any symptoms, but many do, including heavy bleeding with periods.

Ubrogepant is used to treat acute treatment of migraine with or without aura in adults. voxelotor is used to treat sickle cell disease.

Ivacaftor is used to treat patients 12 years of age and older with the most common gene mutation that causes cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a known diabetic for 10 years has incurred community-acquired pneumonia. The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) had set in after 2 weeks of hospitalization. Which of the following cells play a significant role in tissue injury caused by this inflammatory response?
questions.solution:
In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), tissue injury is caused mainly by neutrophils.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury and characterized by inflammation, which causes increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. Damage to the endothelial and alveolar epithelial cells, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage.

In ARDS, neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli, where they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators, including proteases, reactive oxygen species, and cytokines.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy had received multiple warnings for his misbehavior at a certified school, he is considered too difficult to handle. He would be placed in?
questions.solution:
Borstal is a place that falls between a certified institution and a prison, it is where boys over 16 who have misbehaved or are too difficult to handle, are sent. The usual time period for a borstal sentence is 3 years. 

There are about 6 borstals for boys in India but none for girls. Borstals do not come under the Children Act but are governed by the State Inspector General of Prisons

A remand home is an establishment where children are placed under the care of a doctor, psychiatrist, and other trained personnel.

An orphanage is an institution where children who have no home or parents or for some reason can’t be cared for are placed.

Foster homes are arrangements where a family or a couple takes care of a child on a temporary basis.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was found to have hallucinations and vivid dreams following induction with an intravenous anesthetic agent. Which among the following is the most effective drug to reduce the incidence and severity of these post-operative reactions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of emergence reaction or delirium most commonly associated with ketamine. Benzodiazepines are the most effective in reducing the incidence and severity of these postoperative reactions.

Emergence reactions seen with ketamine during emergence from anesthesia are vivid dreaming, hallucinations, extracorporeal experiences, and delusions associated with confusion, euphoria, and fear. These reactions occur in individuals with psychological susceptibility and when large doses of ketamine are rapidly administered. 

Benzodiazepines (BZD) act by facilitating the action of GABA receptors. It acts by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels, thereby hyperpolarizing the neurons and inhibiting their activity.

Uses of Benzodiazepines include

  • Antiepileptics: Lorazepam is the drug of choice for status epilepticus, delirium tremens, catatonia, and patients with liver dysfunction
  • Generalized anxiety disorders, panic disorders
  • Intravenous induction agent - Lorazepam
  • Sedative premedication in children - Midazolam
  • Muscle relaxant 

Other options: 

Phenobarbitone is a barbiturate primarily used in the treatment of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures.

Flumazenil is the benzodiazepine antagonist and is used in BZD overdose.

Carbamazepine is an anti-epileptic used in the management of generalised tonic-clonic and focal seizures. It is also used in bipolar disorder and in trigeminal neuralgias.

questions.text: An intern during his ophthal posting comes across a patient who was complaining of distorted vision. He further explains that whenever he tries to work on graph paper, it's  lines appear as they are bent or obscured as shown in the image. This condition is seen in all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image indicate metamorphopsia. It is usually seen in lesions involving macula. It is not a feature seen in vitreous hemorrhage. Symptoms of vitreous hemorrhage includes sudden painless loss of vision or blurry vision, floaters, red haze.

Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object. It is associated with diseases affecting the macula such as central serous choroidopathy, age-related macular degeneration, diabetic macular edema and macular hole.

questions.text: Patients diagnosed with which variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are likely to have the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worst prognosis.

There are 5 variants of FSGS: 

  • Collapsing variant - poor prognosis
  • Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis
  • Cellular variant
  • Perihilar variant
  • Not otherwise specified - most common

Given below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of the entire glomerular tuft and proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following features would be considered as a contraindication for endoscopic mucosal resection in a patient with early gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic mucosal resection for gastric cancer should not be performed in case of ulcerated gastric cancer as ulceration indicates advanced disease. 

Indications for endoscopic resection of early gastric cancer:

  1. Tumors smaller than 2cm
  2. Tumors limited to the mucosa
  3. No lymphovascular invasion
  4. No ulceration
  5. Well or moderately well-differentiated histopathology.

If any of these are not fulfilled, then gastrectomy with lymph node dissection is indicated.

FDA has approved the use of Nivolumab in combination with other chemotherapeutic drugs, for the initial treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic gastric cancer, GE junction cancer, and esophageal adenocarcinoma. This is the first FDA- approved immunotherapy for the first-line treatment of gastric cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing cholangiography. However, during the procedure, there was difficulty in inserting the catheter through the cystic duct. Which of the following features of the cystic duct is likely to interfere with the passage of the catheter?
questions.solution:
Spiral valves of Heister are the mucosal folds present in the cystic duct. In most cases, they are responsible for causing difficulty in the passage of catheter through the cystic duct.

The mucosa of the cystic duct forms 2–10 crescentic folds which are spirally arranged to form the spiral valve of Heister, also called spiral folds. These are continuous with those in the neck of the gallbladder. The function of these spiral folds is unknown but they may help to preserve the patency of this narrow, tortuous duct.

The cystic duct drains the gallbladder into the common hepatic duct. It unites with the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct.

Note: Tortuous course of the right hepatic artery, also known as Moynihan's hump or caterpillar hump, is a rare but important anomaly to be recognized to prevent intraoperative vascular and biliary injuries during surgical procedures involving the liver and biliary apparatus.

questions.text: Pramlintide is a __________
questions.solution:
Pramlintide is a synthetic analogue of amylin used in the management of diabetes. 

Islet amyloid peptide (amylin) is produced from pancreatic beta-cell. It acts in specific regions of hindbrain resulting in a reduction in glucagon release, delayed gastric emptying, and satiety. It is approved for the treatment of types 1 and 2 diabetes as an adjunct in patients who take insulin with meals. The most common adverse effects are nausea and hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation.
questions.solution:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 French suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100mmHg.

Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically, as it can produce a vagal response due to stimulation in the posterior pharynx, resulting in apnea and/or bradycardia.

The steps in neonatal resuscitation follow the ABCs, Airway, Breathing, and Circulation.

The neonatal resuscitation algorithm is given below:

Chest compression should be initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90/minutes. The ratio of chest compression to ventilation is 3: 1 (90 compressions: 30 breaths). The thumb technique (preferred) and 2 finger technique are the two different techniques used for performing chest compression. Umbilical vein cannulation is the preferred method for the administration of medications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old, G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL).  Which of the following is not recommended in AMTSL according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Sustained uterine massage is not recommended according to WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping for at least 1-3 minutes. This reduces rates of anemia in infants.
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women

Note: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical.

Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL yet may be recommended by some and to be considered with the warning that evidence for this practice is not strong.

questions.text: A young male was brought to the hospital following a bike accident. Maxillary fractures were present, associated with CSF rhinorrhea. A CT scan reveals fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. What type of Le Fort fracture is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Le Fort-II fracture is seen in the above given clinical scenario.

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture.

  • Fracture line passes through root of nose, lacrimal bone, floor of orbit, upper part of maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates.
  • X ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla.
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A woman with cervical incompetence is posted for prophylactic McDonald's cerclage. Which of the following statements is false about this procedure?

choices.text: Removal of stitch must be done by 37th week
A mersilene tape is tied around the cervix
Done at the level of internal os

questions.solution:
In McDonald's cerclage, a nonabsorbable suture, such as Mersilene, is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible at the level of the internal os, positioned at the junction where the rugose vaginal epithelium transitions to the smooth vaginal portion of the cervix, below the bladder.

Another cerclage procedure is Modified Shirodker's technique. In this, a non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and is tied posteriorly.

Removal of cerclage should be done by 37 weeks of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labour.

Complications of cervical cerclage:

  • Slipping of suture
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Rupture of membranes
  • Abortion or preterm labour
  • Cervical laceration or scarring

Many patients do not have the classic history that indicates prophylactic cerclage in the late first or early second trimester. Therefore, many cerclage procedures are performed emergently rather than prophylactically

questions.text: An asthmatic patient complains of wheezing and shortness of breath most days of the week. Which of the following therapies is preferred in him?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent asthma for which the preferred therapy is LABA with ICS available as a combination inhaler.

ICS should be started in any patient who needs to use a short-acting beta-2 agonist inhaler for symptomatic control more than twice a week (persistent asthma). 

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: A hypertensive patient died of respiratory distress due to pneumonia caused by COVID-19 (test positive). What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
COVID-19 will be filled in line I (c) of the death certificate, as it is the condition that gave rise to the antecedent cause (pneumonia).

In this patient:

  • I(a)- Disease directly leading to death: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • I(b)- Antecedent cause: Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Condition which gave rise to antecedent cause: COVID-19

Line II is used to record the contributory factors/causes such as diabetes or hypertension.

ICD allows identifying COVID-19 as the underlying cause of death. COVID-19 should be reported in a sequence ending with a terminal condition such as acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Other scenarios:

1. In case of pregnancy, puerperium, or birth leading to death in conjunction with COVID-19, record the sequence of events as usual.

For example: 

  • I(a)- Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- Pneumonia
  • I(c)- Pregnancy complicated by COVID-19

2. If an HIV patient is dead due to ARDS caused by COVID-19

  • I(a)-Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • I(b)- COVID-19
  • Line II (co-morbidities)- HIV disease

3. Note that COVID-19 patients may die of other diseases or accidents, such cases are not deaths due to COVID-19 and should not be certified as such. In case you think COVID-19 aggravated the consequences of the accident/disease, it may be reported in part II.

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: Which of the following is false about panel discussion?

choices.text: It usually consists of four to eight experts
Members of the audience are invited to take part at the end

questions.solution:
A moderator is required to regulate the panel discussion.

In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 experts have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience. No speeches or order is set beforehand. The audience is invited to take part after the panelists speak and ask questions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old wildlife photographer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia. On examination, you notice gingival bleeds and conjunctival hemorrhages. He recently visited a forest in Karnataka that has a large population of monkeys.  Which of these is the vector for the suspected disease?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with exposure to monkeys, fever, myalgia, headache, conjunctival hemorrhage and gingival bleeds is suggestive of Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), which is transmitted by ticks (Haemophysalis spinigera). It is endemic to the forests of Karnataka and Kerala.

The clinical features include:

  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Myalgia 
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hemorrhagic symptoms- hemorrhages in skin, mucosa and gastrointestinal bleeds.

The case fatality rate is about 5 percent. Monkeys are amplifier hosts, rodents are reservoirs and humans are incidental hosts.

A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.

questions.text: A child with a developmental defect of the thymus was referred for further evaluation. Laboratory Investigation reveals the deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. This  syndrome is not associated with:
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Hypocalcemia is seen in DiGeorge syndrome.

A child with a developmental defect of thymus and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 points towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding indicators used to measure the various fluid compartment volumes?

choices.text: Tritium oxide for total body water

questions.solution:
125I-albumin is used to measure plasma volume by indicator-dilution method, not total blood volume.

In an indicator-dilution method, an appropriate indicator is first placed in the fluid compartment, whose volume has to be measured. Once the indicator is evenly distributed throughout the fluid in the compartment, analyzing the amount of the indicator that becomes diluted helps assess the volume of the corresponding fluid compartment.

125Iodine-albumin and Evan's blue dye can also be used to measure the plasma volume. Whereas, total blood volume can be measured using an indicator substance like 51Chromium labelled red blood cells.

Total blood volume can also be calculated after measuring hematocrit using the equation:

Total blood volume = Plasma volume / 1- hematocrit

Note- Blood volume refers to the total amount of fluid circulating within the arteries, capillaries, veins, venules, and chambers of the heart at any time and includes RBCs, WBCs, platelets and plasma. Plasma volume is a component of the total blood volume and accounts for around 60% of the total blood volume

Related Pearl: Indicators for measurement of body fluids

questions.text: A patient underwent a one-step procedure for gestational diabetes screening. Which of the following statements regarding this procedure is false?

choices.text: Fasting blood glucose  ≥ 92 mg/dL  is diagnostic
100 grams of glucose is given after overnight fast

questions.solution:
In one-step procedure, the patient is given 75g of glucose after an overnight fast, and blood glucose is measured hourly for 2 hours. 

Diagnostic criteria with one-step procedure is as follows:

  • Fasting ≥ 92 mg/dL 
  • 1-hour ≥ 180 mg/dL 
  • 2-hour ≥ 153 mg/dL

In two-step approach patient is given glucose and subsequent values measured in two separate steps.

  • Step 1 - the patient is given 50 grams of glucose and blood glucose is measured after one hour. If it is ≥140 mg/dl then the screen is positive and step 2 is done.
  • Step 2 - the patient is given 100g of glucose and values measured hourly, for 3 hours. A diagnosis is made if at least two values are high using one of two methods.

DIPSI (Diabetes In Pregnancy Societies of India) recommends a one-step procedure without regard to the time of the last meal. Here the patient is given 75 grams of oral glucose. A blood glucose value of ≥140 mg/dL after 2-hours is diagnostic.

questions.text: An obstetrician performing clinical pelvimetry finds that the smallest transverse diameter is 8 cm. Which of the following parameters has she assessed?
questions.solution:
The interspinous diameter is the smallest transverse pelvic diameter. 

The interspinous diameter or bispinous diameter is measured in the mid pelvis. It is the distance between the tips of two ischial spines. Normally, it is 10-10.5 cm. 

It is useful in predicting obstructed labor. If the interspinous diameter is too small, the baby's head may get stuck at a higher station. 

Note: The obstetric conjugate is the smallest anteroposterior pelvic diameter measuring 10 cm.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man developed acneiform eruptions, which was later diagnosed to be drug-induced acne. These drug-induced acneiform eruptions are _________
questions.solution:
Drug‐induced acneiform eruptions are monomorphic and inflammatory lesions, with an absence of comedones, often presenting acutely on sites not commonly affected by acne.

The face and upper trunk are most frequently affected.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with a history of serous discharge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Where is the location of the internal opening likely to be?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a fistula-in-ano. Here, the external opening was at 8'O clock which is considered posterior. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline (6’O clock position). Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at 6’O clock position.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the internal posterior midline.

Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: While examining the hypoglossal nerve in a stroke patient, you observe the following finding. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows tongue deviation to the left, and the left genioglossus muscle is paralyzed in the above given clinical scenario.

Actions of genioglossus muscle:

  • When both the right and left genioglossi contract, they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline. When only one muscle contracts, it protrudes and pushes the tongue to the opposite side.
  • It depresses the central part of the tongue.
  • It is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. 

In conditions affecting the hypoglossal nerve, the genioglossus muscle on that side is paralyzed. In such cases, when the patient protrudes the tongue, it deviates towards the affected side due to the muscle contraction on the normal side.

The genioglossi are attached to the genial tubercle present on the mandible. This prevents the tongue from falling backwards and obstructing respiration. Hence this muscle is known as the safety muscle of the tongue.

questions.text: A 30-year-old psychiatric patient consumed some liquid from a bottle accidentally. Clinical examination shows a peculiar rash as shown in the image. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic boiled lobster appearance. It is seen in poisoning with boric acid.

In severe poisoning with boric acid, a beefy red skin rash, most often affecting palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum, is seen. The intense erythema is followed by extensive exfoliation.

Boric acid is used as an antiseptic and insecticide.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have colonic cancer on routine colonoscopy and biopsy. His father had developed a similar colonic cancer and died at the age of 40. His family history is remarkable for endometrial and urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome/Hereditary non-polyposis colonic cancer (HNPCC). HNPCC results from a defect in the DNA mismatch repair system.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant disorder that leads to the development of carcinoma in the cecum and proximal colon. One defective copy of the gene is inherited while the other gene undergoes a loss of function mutation.  

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome and microsatellite instability. A microsatellite is a sequence of 1-6 nucleotides found repeated throughout the genome. They are found in normal individuals at a constant length. In patients with DNA mismatch repair, these lengths are variable leading to mutated alleles. 

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with regulated genomic instability in lymphoid cells develop T and B cell neoplasia. 

Option C: Patients with a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway develop xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option D: Patients with defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system may develop Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition where a person has morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy and suspects a faithful partner of infidelity.

Delusional Misidentification Syndromes:

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: This is a very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppelganger syndrome: This is a delusion of subjective doubles, where the person feels that he/she has his/her own impostor (doppelganger). 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of difficulty breathing. Chest X-Ray shows "eggshell" calcification. Histopathology of the lung shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's radiological and histopathological features are seen in silicosis.

Eggshell calcification refers to the fine rim of calcification seen at the periphery of a mass (usually a lymph node)

Silicotic nodules are characterized by concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center in the hilar lymph nodes and the upper zones of the lungs.

When it is rimmed by thin sheets of calcification in the lymph nodes, they are appreciated radiographically as “eggshell” calcification.

Image: Histology of silicotic nodule showing a central area of whorled collagen fibers, with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages and rim of lymphocytes

Other options:

Option B- Asbestosis shows ferruginous bodies on histopathology
Option C-Lung hamartomas appear as well circumcised nodules/masses. They do not show silicotic nodules in histopathology.
Option D-Tuberculosis present with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Histopathology reveals caseous necrosis with multinucleated giant cells.

Related Pearl: Eggshell calcification of lymph node on chest X-ray

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Post-irradiation lymphoma
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Tuberculosis

questions.text: The following is an RBC from venous blood. Identify the “?” in the image.
questions.solution:
Cl- ion is exchanged for HCO3- across the RBC membrane.

The diagram explains the chloride shift that occurs in an RBC of venous blood as it carries CO2 to the lungs. This shift is mediated by an anion exchanger called AE 1 (Band 3). When this occurs, the osmolality inside an RBC is increased due to the chloride ions. This causes RBCs to absorb more water and swell up which accounts for the increased PCV in venous blood compared to the arterial blood.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. The X-ray image is given below. CT scan of the chest reveals metastasis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the sunburst appearance of the tumor at the metaphyseal end of a long bone, which is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

Other options:

Option A - Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

Option D - Secondary metastasis from the prostate is typically densely osteosclerotic, in contrast to osteolytic renal and thyroid lesions. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Local and distal staging includes X-rays and MRI of the whole affected bone, bone scintigraphy, and CT scan of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. The most sensitive imaging modality for identifying metastases is the whole-body MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following action will be lost due to injury of the structure D, marked in the given image of the popliteal fossa?

choices.text: Loss of flexion of great toe

questions.solution:
The structures marked as D in the above image is common peroneal nerve. Injury of this nerve results in Loss of eversion.

Injury to common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss along the anterior and lateral side of the leg, dorsum of foot including the medial side of great toe.

     

Common peroneal nerve injury is most commonly injured at lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula.

 The popliteal fossa is a diamond-shaped area found on the posterior side of the knee.

Its contents are (medial to lateral):

  • Popliteal artery
  • Popliteal vein
  • Tibial nerve
  • Common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve)

The other structures marked as A, B, and C in the above image are popliteal artery, popliteal Vein and tibial nerve respectively.

questions.text: A research professor wishes to study the diffusion properties of the plasma membrane, from a cell homogenate. Which of the following enzymatic markers would help him isolate the plasma membrane from the other components of a cell?
questions.solution:
5′-Nucleotidase is used as a marker for the plasma membrane.

Enzymes as markers of organelle and membranes:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with periodic abdominal pain. The pain is associated with meals and is relieved by antacids. Physical examination is unremarkable. Endoscopy shows a mucosal ulcer. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of peptic ulcers is bleeding.

An ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum causes bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery. Gastric ulcer on the lesser curvature of the stomach causes bleeding from the left gastric artery.

Other complications are perforation, obstruction, and malignant transformation.

Note: The most common cause of death in peptic ulcers is perforation followed by bleeding. Perforation accounts for two-thirds of ulcer deaths.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed a loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve, which is likely to be injured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue
