questions.text: A young man was started on the drug which is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of platelet after percutaneous coronary intervention. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients. 

Side effects include bleeding and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura in rare cases. Administration of prasugrel with an anticoagulant or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug is avoided as it may increase the risk of bleeding. Contraindicated in patients above 75 years of age and those with a history of cerebrovascular disease.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Tirofiban acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. It has a short duration of action and is used for the management of patients with non–ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome.

Option C: Eptifibatide acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: A patient complains of a foamy discharge from both eyes for two weeks associated with irritation and discomfort. The patient’s left eye is shown in the image below. How is this condition treated?
questions.solution:
The image and the history suggest angular conjunctivitis and the condition is treated using topical tetracycline.

Angular conjunctivitis is caused typically by Moraxella lacunata and Staphylococcus aureus (rare cause).

The nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis are the usual sources of infection. It spreads from the nasal cavity to the eye through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.

It is characterized by the inflammation and reddening of the inner and outer canthi with the excoriation of the skin. There is a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. There is discomfort and irritation of the eyes. Tetracycline ointment is used in management.

questions.text: You are a radiation oncology resident explaining the harmful effects of radiation to a patient. Which of the following is not a deterministic effect of the same?
questions.solution:
Mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories: stochastic and nonstochastic/deterministic effects.

 

Stochastic effects

 Deterministic effects
Description These are chance effects. The probability of occurrence increases with increasing absorbed dose, but severity does not depend on the amount of absorbed dose. This is called the 'all or none' phenomenon. Increases in severity with increasing absorbed dose in affected individuals.
Threshold level It cannot be set. It can be set.
Examples  Genetic effect, development of cancer Organ atrophy, fibrosis, lens opacification, blood changes, decrease in sperm count, irreversible skin damage,fetal abnormalities

questions.text: The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by ____.
questions.solution:
The iceberg phenomenon in epidemiology is not shown by measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension and mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

The iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness on walking a few yards. He adds that he has an uncomfortable awareness of his heartbeat, especially on lying down. Examination reveals widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula. Which of the following would be the most likely auscultatory finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of breathlessness and palpitations, along with the findings of widened pulse pressure and pulsating uvula, is suggestive of aortic regurgitation(AR). The most likely auscultatory finding in this patient is Austin-Flint murmur.

Aortic regurgitation may either be caused due to valvular heart diseases like endocarditis and rheumatic fever; diseases of the aortic root, like aortic dissection and medial degeneration, or a combination of both.

Men are more commonly affected than women. Patients present with features of an uncomfortable awareness of the heartbeat, especially on lying down, and exertional dyspnea.

The dyspnea is followed by orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and excessive diaphoresis. Anginal chest pain may occur, both at rest as well as during exertion; these episodes of chest pain can be prolonged and often do not respond well to sublingual nitroglycerin.

Auscultatory findings in aortic regurgitation include a diastolic murmur and Austin Flint murmur. The former is a typically high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur. It is called a 'cooing dove' murmur when the murmur is of musical quality. Its presence usually signifies the eversion or perforation of an aortic cusp. 

An Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur. It is created by the regurgitant stream displacing the anterior leaflet of the normal mitral valve.

Other options:

Options B and D: Opening snap and Graham Steel murmur are seen in mitral stenosis. The Graham Steel murmur is a decrescendo diastolic murmur seen in mitral stenosis patients who have developed pulmonary hypertension, and resultant pulmonary regurgitation.

Option C: Gallavardin phenomenon is seen in aortic stenosis, where the coarse systolic murmur of aortic stenosis may sound higher pitched and more acoustically pure at the apex.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: Which of the following is a prescriptive screening?

choices.text: Screening of sex workers for HIV

questions.solution:
Screening for cervical cancer is an example of prescriptive screening.

Screening is defined as the search for an unrecognized illness in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations or procedures. In general, screening may be classified into two types:

  • Prescriptive screening
  • Prospective screening

The differences between them are highlighted in the table below:

  Prescriptive screening Prospective screening
Definition It is the screening test done in an individual for his/her own benefit It is the screening test done in an individual for the benefit of others
Purpose To detect cases and start the appropriate treatment To control disease spread by isolating the individual and providing treatment
Request for screening There is no specific request by the patient/individual. The physician responsible for the patient's care decides to perform the test. Specific requests come from to screen certain individuals.
Examples

Screening for:
- Bacteriuria in pregnancy
- Breast/cervical cancer
- Urine for sugar
- Deafness in children
- Iron deficiency anemia
- Pulmonary tuberculosis
- Newborn screening

 Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases to protect the population in the home country like screening of travellers coming from China, under request from the government to prevent the transmission of coronavirus to the Indian population.
-Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
- Screening of blood donors to prevent transmission of infection to the recipient.

questions.text: Shown below is a skin lesion. Which of the following is not a criterion to assess its malignant potential?
questions.solution:
The image shown above depicts a nevus. Diameter >6 mm is the diagnostic clue for the transformation of a nevus to a melanoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text: A child presenting with open globe injury. Which induction agent should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Ketamine should be avoided in a child presenting with open globe injury as it can increase intraocular pressure.

It usually raises arterial blood pressure and also does not relax extraocular muscles and may cause nystagmus and blepharospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following Korotkoff sounds corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in a patient with aortic regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Muffled sound corresponds to diastolic blood pressure in aortic regurgitation.

In aortic regurgitation, the pulse pressure is widened and the Korotkoff sounds often do not disappear even when the sphygmomanometer cuff is fully deflated. Hence, diastolic pressure is recorded at the pressure that corresponds to muffling of korotkoff sounds.

Related Pearl: Phases of Korotkoff Sounds

Phase

Description

K-1

Tapping sound

Corresponds to systolic BP

K-2

Murmur (soft swishing sound)

K-3

Loud and clear tapping sound

K-4

Muffled sound

K-5

Disappearance of sounds

Corresponds to Diastolic BP

NOTE- K-4 (muffled sound) corresponds to DBP in-

  • Adults after exercise
  • Children
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Patients with arteriovenous fistulas for hemodialysis

questions.text: A forensic expert receives the skull of a gunshot victim. What is the sequence of gunshots in this case?
questions.solution:
The sequence of gunshots, in this case, is 1→ 2→ 3 according to Puppe's rule.

Puppe's rule states that the path of a second fracture line does not cross the path of an existing fracture line that appears or was caused before it. This helps the forensic expert determine the chronology (order) in which the bullets were lodged into the skull. 

Puppe's rule is used in forensic examination of skull fractures caused by multiple blunt force vectors as well, as it is not limited to the examination of bullet injuries only.

questions.text: All of the following microorganisms have the appearance as shown in the image below except ___________
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic bipolar staining giving a safety pin appearance. Clostridium difficile does not show bipolar staining.

In smears stained with Giemsa or methylene blue, the following organisms show bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear.

  • Yersinia pestis
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Calymmatobacterium granulomatis/ Klebsiella granulomatis/ 
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who is on ART for AIDS presented with difficulty in vision. Fundoscopic examination revealed the following finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following subfamilies of the Herpesviridae family encompasses the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Pizza pie appearance on fundoscopy in an immunocompromised person is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. It belongs to beta viruses subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses (e.g. HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus)
  • Beta herpes viruses (e.g. CMV)
  • Gamma herpesviruses (e.g. EBV)

Alpha viruses

 Beta viruses Gamma viruses
Short replicative cycle – 12-18 hours Replicative cycle - >24 hours variable
Latency – sensory ganglia Latency – salivary glands and other organs Lymphocyte specific
Ex: HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus

Ex: CMV

HHV6

HHV7

Ex: EBV

HHV8

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed with Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?

choices.text: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
Woody hard swelling in the parotid region

questions.solution:
Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth.

There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus. The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edema may also be present.

Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage show salted pork appearance.

questions.text: If at a particular pH the concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50 % non-ionic then_____________
questions.solution:
If at a particular pH the concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50 % non-ionic then pH = pKa of a drug.

pKa is defined as the pH at which a drug exists as 50% ionized (hydrophilic) and 50% unionized (lipophilic). The ratio of nonionized to ionized drug at any pH may be calculated from the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: A nurse sustained a needlestick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. How long should he be taking the prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg for 4 weeks. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

The protocol followed is :Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28 - day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

Note: The NACO October 2018 guidelines recommend the two drug regimen but the recent MOHFW JAN 2020 recommends the three drug regimen as per WHO December 2018 guidelines as the preferred treatment for PEP in HIV.

questions.text: Normal quiet breathing is caused by repetitive inspiratory signals from which of the following neurons?
questions.solution:
Normal quiet breathing is caused only by repetitive inspiratory signals from the dorsal respiratory group of neurons.

Ventral groups of neurons fire, when forceful expiration is needed like during heavy exercise.

Pneumotaxic center limits the duration of inspiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with axillary metastasis. Which of the following is seen in the draining lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
In lymph nodes draining cancers, reticular hyperplasia is prominent.

Reticular hyperplasia, also called sinus histiocytosis, refers to an increase in the number and size of the cells that line lymphatic sinusoids. This form of hyperplasia may be particularly prominent in lymph nodes draining cancers such as carcinoma of the breast. The lining lymphatic endothelial cells are markedly hypertrophied and macrophages are greatly increased in numbers, resulting in the expansion and distension of the sinuses.

The image below shows sinus histiocytosis.

Follicular hyperplasia is caused by stimuli that activate the humoral immune response. e.g., Rheumatoid arthritis, toxoplasmosis, the early stage of HIV infection. 

Paracortical and cortical hyperplasia are caused by stimuli that trigger T-cell-mediated immune responses. e.g., Acute viral infections like infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man diagnosed with erythema multiforme is found to have atypical target lesions. The number of zones that would be seen in this atypical target lesions is _____________
questions.solution:
Atypical target lesions seen in erythema multiforme have only 2 zones.

Typical target lesions are characteristically seen in Erythema multiforme. It is also called an iris lesion or bull's eye lesion.

  • They have 3 or more zones.
    • Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
    • Middle paler zone of edema
    • Outer ring of erythema with a well-defined edge

The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes. The lesions appear in successive crops for a few days and fade in 1–2 weeks. Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones.

Erythema Multiforme

Erythema Multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity to either infection or drugs.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

It presents clinically with macular, popular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions.

The image below shows typical target lesions.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia.

Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. The clinical outcomes are independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels.

Clinical features of myxedema crisis include:

  • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma)
  • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs.
  • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension.
  • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with unhealthy eating practices now complains of constipation. He took bisacodyl, following which he had symptomatic relief. Which group of drugs does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative.

Stimulant laxatives act by irritation of the intestinal mucosa and direct action on myenteric plexus neurons stimulating motility and secretion.

Examples of stimulant/irritant laxatives are:

  • Bisacodyl
  • Sodium picosulfate
  • Anthraquinones like senna, cascara sagrada
  • Castor oil

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding a stable atherosclerotic plaque?
questions.solution:
A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells.

These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque.

Stable plaque Vulnerable plaque
Dense collagen Less collagen
Thick fibrous cap Thin fibrous cap
Minimal inflammation Increased inflammation
Less extracellular lipid Abundant extracellular lipid
Abundant smooth muscle cells Few smooth muscle cells
Few foam cells Abundant  foam cells

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.

Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.

Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity:

  1. Liver
  2. Pancreas
  3. Myocardium
  4. Pituitary gland
  5. Adrenal gland
  6. Thyroid
  7. Parathyroid gland
  8. Joints
  9. Skin

questions.text: You are prescribing estrogen therapy for a woman with hot flushes. What is the minimum number of days in a month during which you should combine it with progesterone?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone must be added to estrogen therapy. This reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%. 

The risk of cancer with estrogen therapy is dose and duration-dependent. Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer. 

Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of ganglioside?
questions.solution:
Glycerol is not a component of ganglioside.

Gangliosides belong to non-phosphorylated lipids (compound lipids). It contains ceramide (sphingosine + fatty acid) and oligosaccharide containing N- acetyl neuraminic acid.

Related Pearl: Types of Sphingolipids

Glycosphingolipid

Cerebrosides

Gangliosides

Globosides

Sphingophospholipid

Sphingomyelin

questions.text: Identify the traction shown in the image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Gallow’s traction which is used to treat fracture of shaft femur in children less than 2 years and less than 12 kg.

Older children are treated with Russell’s traction or Thomas splint. After 2–4 weeks, when the fracture has sufficiently progressed, it is replaced by ‘hip spica’.

Russell's traction:

The given image shows Perkins' traction which is used to treat fractures of the shaft femur in adults.

Smith’s traction is a skeletal traction indicated for supracondylar fracture of the humerus

Related Pearl: Some Important Traction and Their Uses

1) Gallow/Bryant traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in children below 2 years

2) Perkin traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in adults

3) Russell’s traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Trochanteric fractures

4) Dunlop/Smith traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Supracondylar fracture humerus

5) Buck's traction: 

  • Most common lower limb traction
  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Femoral fractures, acetabular and hip fractures

6)Crutchfield traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

7) Head halter traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

8) Halo-pelvic traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Scoliosis

questions.text: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in this condition?
questions.solution:
The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA antibodies in the mesangial cell.

Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases characterized by the deposition of immune complexes.

Mesangial cell diseases:

  • IgA nephropathy
  • IgM nephropathy
  • Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Class II lupus nephritis
  • Diabetic nephropathy

Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed as a first-line drug for a patient with painful diabetic neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is a selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

  • First-line: 
    • Lidoderm 5% patch
    • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
    • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
    • Duloxetine
  • Second-line: 
    • Carbamazepine
    • Phenytoin
    • Venlafaxine
    • Tramadol
  • Third-line:
    • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the ER with complaints of severe pain behind his chest bone associated with sweating and giddiness. He has a blood pressure of 86/54 mmHg. The electrocardiogram recorded is given below. Which of the following would be efficient management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the ECG showing ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF are suggestive of an inferior wall myocardial infarction. His vitals shows that he has hypotension and hence, the efficient management in this situation would be a brisk administration of fluids to combat the cardiogenic shock that would set in, if untreated.

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

Sublingual nitroglycerine, intravenous morphine, and intravenous furosemide can reduce the preload and hence should be avoided in an MI complicated by hypotension.

In the setting of inferior wall infarction, signs of cardiogenic shock should prompt the suspicion of a right ventricular infarction. And the same can be evidenced by ST elevation in the right precordial leads (V4R, V5R, V6R). The diagnosis of right ventricular MI is suspected in patients with inferior-wall MI, clear lung fields (no added sounds onauscultation), and shock. If a right ventricular infarction is suspected, avoid nitrates and increase volume to ensure adequate preload. The right ventricle has less myocardium than the left and relies on adequate preload to function properly. If the right ventricle is damaged, preload reduction from nitrates may result in significant hypotension.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A COVID-positive patient was rushed to the emergency on the 3rd day of illness due to difficulty in breathing. His Spo2 was 84%, and ABG values showed normal PaCO2 with low PaO2. He was mechanically ventilated in view of his deteriorating condition. Despite best efforts, the patient couldn't be saved and succumbed to death. What type of respiratory failure would have caused this?
questions.solution:
The patient had died because of COVID pneumonia. The respiratory failure seen in pneumonia is Type I respiratory failure (acute hypoxemic type).

Type I respiratory failure occurs due to alveolar flooding (caused by alveolar haemorrhage, pulmonary oedema, lung injury, pneumonia) and subsequent ventilation-perfusion mismatch and intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Causes include

  • Sepsis
  • COVID-19
  • Gastric aspiration
  • Pneumonia
  • Near-drowning
  • Multiple blood transfusions
  • Pancreatitis.

Management includes prone positioning, fluid conservation, masks, and high-flow oxygen delivery systems.

Other options:

Option A: Type IV respiratory failure occurs due to hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles during shock. Intubation and mechanical ventilation can cause a redistribution of cardiac output to vital organs.

Option B: Type III respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. It is more common in the postoperative period. Treatment includes frequent changes in position, chest physiotherapy, upright positioning, and control of incisional and/or abdominal pain. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation may also be used to reverse regional atelectasis.

Option C: Type II or hypercapnic respiratory failure is characterized by alveolar hypoventilation and the inability to effectively eliminate carbon dioxide. Therefore the levels of PaCO2 are high. Management is aimed at treating the underlying cause(s) of ventilatory failure. Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask can be used. 

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

 

Type Name Mechanism Associated conditions
I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure

Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology.

Low pO2

Normal/ low pCO2

High (pAO2-paO2)

Sepsis

Gastric aspiration

Pneumonia

Near-drowning

Multiple blood transfusions

Pancreatitis
II

Hypoxemia with hypercapnia

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

Low pO2

High pCO2

Normal (pAO2-paO2)

Drug overdose

Brainstem injury

Sleep-disordered breathing

Severe hypothyroidism

Myasthenia gravis

Guillain-Barre syndrome

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
III Peri-operative respiratory failure Results from lung atelectasis. After general anesthesia.
IV Shock Results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock Cardiogenic shock.

 

pO2- partial pressure of oxygen

pCO2- partial pressure of carbon dioxide

(pAO2-paO2)- alveolar- arterial oxygen gradient

questions.text: The given image shows normal His Bundle Electrogram. The deflection shown by the arrow indicates _______
questions.solution:
The arrow mark shows V deflection of HBE which indicates ventricular depolarization.

His bundle electrogram (HBE):

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE. It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

PA interval

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

Conduction in Bundle of His and bundle branches

questions.text: A 6-year-old kid was brought to the emergency department by his father, as the kid had accidentally put some foreign body into his nose while playing. The ENT resident removes it with the help of the following instrument. This instrument can also be used for ________.

choices.text: Nasal packing and reducing nasal septum fracture
Nasal packing and reducing nasal bone fracture
Reducing nasal septum and nasal bone fractures

questions.solution:
The above image shows Tilley’s forceps.

It is used for nasal packing, ear dressing, removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

Other options:

Asch's septum forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum.

Walsham forceps is used for disimpacting and reducing fractures of the nasal bone.

questions.text:
A third-year medical student was asked the draw the Ohngren’s line. The line drawn by him is as shown in the below image(dotted line) where "A" and "B"  represents maxillary tumour growth
below and above the Ohngren’s line. Which of the following option is true regarding the prognosis of maxillary tumour?

choices.text: Both A and B has poor prognosis
Both A and B has Good prognosis
A has Poor prognosis and B has Good prognosis
A has Good prognosis and B has Poor prognosis

questions.solution:
"A" has Good prognosis and "B" has Poor prognosis is the true statement.

Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through medial canthus of eye and angle of mandible.

It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.

  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for routine immunization. According to the National Immunisation Schedule, which of the following  would you administer?
questions.solution:
At 5 years of age, the 2nd booster dose of DPT must be given along with the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A.

1st booster dose of DPT is given at 16 – 24 months of age.

1st dose of vitamin A is given at 9th month and the 2nd dose is given at 16 months followed by one dose every 6 months thereafter until the age of 5.

Note: DPT booster + Vitamin A is a better answer than DPT booster + OPV because the 9th (final) dose of vitamin A must be given at 5 years but OPV at 5 years is an optional vaccine.

*Give Td-2 or booster doses before 36 weeks of pregnancy. However, give these even if more than 36 weeks have passed. Give Td to a woman in labor, if she has not previously received Td.

**JE vaccine is introduced in select endemic districts after the campaigns. Intramuscular (killed inactivated) vaccine is gradually replacing the live attenuated vaccine. This change is because the killed vaccines are more effective and require fewer doses.

***The 2nd to 9th doses of vitamin A can be administered to children 1–5 years old during biannual rounds, in collaboration with ICDS.

questions.text: A young man starts profusely sweating and hyperventilating whenever he enters an elevator or closed space and tries to avoid it. He also has palpitations, dizziness, and fear. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which the person develops anxiety symptoms and fear of entering a closed space is suggestive of claustrophobia, a type of specific phobia.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. To diagnose this condition, the prerequisites are the development of intense anxiety or panic, when exposed to the feared object. 

The main defense mechanisms in phobias include displacement, projection, and avoidance. The DSM-5 includes distinctive types of specific phobia:

  • Animal type - e.g. cats, dogs
  • Natural environment type - e.g. storms
  • Blood-injection­ injury type - e.g. needles
  • Situational type - e.g. cars, elevators, planes
  • Other types - for specific phobias that do not fit into the previous four types

Treatment includes behavioral therapy like exposure-based and systematic desensitization. Pharmacotherapy with benzodiazepines, psychotherapy, or combined therapy directed to the attacks may also be beneficial. 

Other options: 

Option A: Agoraphobia is a fear of open places. 

Option B: Acrophobia is a fear of heights. 

Option D: Ailurophobia is a fear of cats. 

Related Pearl: Specific phobia

Present in 10% of the population.

Clinical features:

  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for > 6 months
  • Usually develops in childhood, can develop after a traumatic event
  • Avoidance behavior

Treatment:

  • Behavioral therapy (exposure-based, systematic desensitization) is the treatment of choice
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines may help acutely

 

Phobia Object
Acarophobia Small objects
Acrophobia High places
Agoraphobia Open or crowded places, leaving familiar setting of home
Aichmophobia Pointed objects
Ailurophobia Cats
Algophobia Pain

Autophobia Being alone, or of self

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have often noticed her staring blankly for a few minutes, which is sometimes associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she does not have a problem with maintaining her posture. The EEG of the child is given below. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and EEG showing a generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern, is diagnostic of absence seizures. Of the given antiepileptic drugs, sodium valproate is the first-line agent to treat this condition.

Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without loss of postural control. There is no postictal confusion. The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes:

  • Rapid blinking of the eyelids
  • Chewing movements
  • Small-amplitude clonic movements of the hands

Hyperventilation has a tendency to provoke absence seizures.

Ethosuximide and valproic acid are the only 2 FDA-approved first-line antiepileptic drugs for the absence seizures. However, between these 2 drugs, ethosuximide would be a better first-line treatment choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizures.

questions.text: A miner with cough, dyspnea on exertion and chest pain was diagnosed with silicotuberculosis. Which of the following is incorrect about his disease?

choices.text: Children of these patients do not get the disease

questions.solution:
The sputum sample is usually negative for AFB (acid-fast bacilli) in patients diagnosed with silicotuberculosis.

Patients with silicosis are particularly susceptible to pulmonary tuberculosis infection, a condition known as silicotuberculosis. Children and women exposed to silicotuberculosis patients do not develop tuberculosis (Option B). Post-mortem examinations done on silicotuberculosis patients fail to prove the existence of tuberculosis.

Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis. It occurs in industries such as sandblasting, pottery and ceramics, mining, and construction. It presents as cough, dyspnea, and chest pain and the advanced disease usually affects the total lung capacity (Option C). It affects the upper lobe of the lung and is characterized by dense nodular fibrosis (Option D) which is irreversible. Chest X-ray shows snowstorm appearance in the lung fields while eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes can be seen on a CT.

Related Pearl: Some common pneumoconiosis

Eggshell calcification refers to fine calcification seen at the periphery of a lymph node. Causes are -

  • Silicosis (most common)

  • Histoplasmosis

questions.text: A farmer while working in the field had a minor cut injury to the right foot. Following this, he developed rashes in the limbs. A few days later he presents with a dry unproductive cough. Laboratory investigations showed eosinophilia and chest X-ray showed patchy pneumonitis. All of the following parasites can be responsible for this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenarios of a farmer developing a dry unproductive cough following a cut in the foot, along with eosinophilia, and chest X-ray showing patchy pneumonitis is suggestive of Loeffler’s syndrome. Of the listed parasites, Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome. 

Development of rash after injury indicates skin penetration by larvae of the hookworms Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus, and the roundworm Strongyloides stercoralis. After penetrating the skin, larvae migrate within a day or two via the bloodstream into the lungs. When passing through the lungs, the patient may develop Loeffler syndrome.

Loeffler's syndrome is a disease in which eosinophils accumulate in the lung in response to a parasitic infection. It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough, low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia.

Parasites causing Loeffler’s syndrome:

  • Migrating larva of
    • Strongyloides stercoralis
    • Hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus)
    • Ascaris 
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Eggs of Paragonimus westermani
  • Entamoeba histolytica

questions.text: A young patient on awakening after surgery complains of severe pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Which of the following drug is better suited to rescue this patient from pain?
questions.solution:
Fentanyl is better suited to rescue this patient from pain. It is the most commonly used drug in rescue analgesia due to its rapid pain control and less incidence of adverse effects.

Rescue Analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize severe post-operative pain. Mild pain can be treated with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl. Fentanyl (20 to 25 μg) is commonly used for this purpose to rapidly achieve analgesia. 

Fentanyl is a potent short-acting opioid analgesic. It is lipophilic in nature.

Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone in rescue analgesia. It controls the pain more rapidly than morphine (option A) and also reduces the incidence of PONV i.e postoperative nausea and vomiting. While oxycodone (option C) has good analgesic action when given systemically for visceral pain relief, it has an increased incidence of adverse effects when compared to fentanyl. Hence, fentanyl is preferred over morphine and oxycodone for rescue analgesia. 

Other uses are: to manage pain before surgical procedures, supplement in balanced anesthesia, in combination with benzodiazepines in diagnostic, endoscopic, angiographic, and minor procedures, and as an adjuvant in spinal anesthesia.

Hypertonia can often occur following a rapid infusion of fentanyl and hence a muscle relaxant is often supplemented. Respiratory depression is a common side effect. Other side effects include nausea, vomiting, and itching.

Note: Codeine is a less potent opioid agonist. Oral codeine is useful to suppress cough but has mild to moderate analgesic properties. When given intravenously, it can cause profound hypotension, and hence it is not recommended.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to you for her first antenatal visit. You discover on routine investigations that her blood group is B negative while her husband is B positive. You reassure her and explain to her the role of anti-D injections in the prevention of red cell alloimmunization. Which of the following is false about anti-D immunoprophylaxis?

choices.text: The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is 60 days
First dose is given at 28 weeks of gestation to D-negative, unsensitized Rh-negative women
Second dose is given within 72 hours of delivery and only if the baby is Rh-positive with direct Coombs’ test negative
300 μg of anti-D immune globulin can neutralize 15 mL of fetal RBCs

questions.solution:
The half-life of anti-D immune globulin is not 60 days. Hence, option A is false regarding anti-D immunoprophylaxis.

The half-life of anti-D immune globulin ranges from 16 to 24 days, depending on the preparation. (Option A) This is the reason why it is given in both the third trimester and following delivery. 

All D-negative, unsensitized women should receive anti-D Ig at approximately 28 weeks of gestation (Option B). The second dose is given within 72 hours of the delivery and the newborn is D-positive (Option C).

300 μg or 1500 IU is the standard intramuscular dose of anti-D Ig. It will protect the average-sized mother from fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of whole fetal blood or 15 mL of fetal red cells (Option D). Kleihauer-Betke test is used to estimate the approximate volume of fetal blood that enters the maternal circulation.

The protocol for Rh isoimmunization is as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is a nonstructural gene of HIV?
questions.solution:
The tat gene (trans-activating gene) is a non-structural gene. 

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

  • Structural genes- Genes coding for structural protiens:  
    • gag- Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
    • env- Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
    • pol- Codes for enzymes: Polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease
  • Non-structural and regulatory genes:
    • tat- Trans-activating gene
    • nef- Negative factor gene
    • rev- Regulator of virus gene
    • vif- Viral infectivity factor gene
    • vpu- (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
    • vpr- Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
    • LTR- Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has been brought to the hospital following blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. On examination, it was found that the structures passing through the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra have been injured. All of the following structures are injured in this case except?
questions.solution:
The most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra is the aortic opening. The right vagus nerve is not injured in the given case as it passes through the oesophageal opening while all these other structures are injured.

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings are the aortic hiatus, the oesophagal hiatus, and the caval hiatus.

The aortic opening is the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening. It is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra and the corresponding intervertebral disc. It is bounded by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, the vertebral column posteriorly, and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly. 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are,

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: An intern, during his medicine postings, was asked to calculate the cardiac index of a patient whose heart rate is 80 beats/min and respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient's heart was able to pump 75 mL of blood from each ventricle per heartbeat and the body surface area was determined to be 1.5 sq. meters. What would be the value of the calculated cardiac index?
questions.solution:
The cardiac index is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of the body surface. It would be 4 L/min/m2. 

Cardiac index = Cardiac output/body surface area

Cardiac output is given as follows:

Cardiac output = heart rate X stroke volume.

The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped out of each ventricle per beat (i.e. 75 mL in the given question) and heart rate is given as 80 beats/min.

Cardiac Output = heart rate X stroke volume = 80 X 75 mL = 6 L/min

Therefore, cardiac index = 6 L/min/1.5 m2 = 4 L/min/m2 

It has been observed that cardiac output increases proportionally with an increase in body surface area. Hence, cardiac output is frequently expressed in terms of cardiac index.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: You are working as a research associate on clinical trials of a new drug for migraine.  What is the dose of the test drug that is usually not exceeded in phase 0 studies?
questions.solution:
The dose of the test drug in phase 0 studies usually does not exceed 100mcg.

Phase 0 studies are also called micro-dosing studies. Very low doses of drugs, usually 1/100th of the estimated human dose or a maximum of 100 mcg are administered to healthy human volunteers. They are done to obtain pharmacokinetic data in humans at a very early stage of drug development. It does not provide any information on therapeutic or toxic effects of the drug. The micro-dosing stage is not mandatory and is not clearly categorized by regulatory authorities yet.

questions.text: Which among the following is the earliest internal change in putrefaction?

choices.text: Brownish discolouration of the inner surface of aorta
Lungs reduced to a small black mass

questions.solution:
The earliest internal change in putrefaction is the brownish discolouration of the inner surface of the blood vessels especially aorta.

Internally decomposition proceeds more slowly than the surface. Colour change in viscera varies from dark red to black. The viscera becomes softer and greasy to touch and finally breakdown into a soft disintegrating mass.

First external sign: Greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.

Sulphmethemoglobin is the agent imparting greenish color.

The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—->Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: A young child affected with an inborn error of metabolism presented with mental retardation and ectopia lentis. On further investigation, the enzyme cystathionine-beta synthase was found to be absent in the child. What is the typical lens subluxation seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of homocystinuria, which is most commonly associated with inferonasal subluxation of lens.

Deficiency of Cystathionine β synthase produces homocystinuria which is a autosomal recessive condition. It is characterized by developmental delay, ectopia lentis, progressive mental retardation, skeleton abnormalities.

Congenital subluxation of the lens is called ectopia lentis. Ectopia lentis associated with syndromes include,

  • Marfan’s syndrome: Superotemporal subluxation of lens
  • Homocystinuria: Inferonasal subluxation of the lens
  • Weill–Marchesani: Downward, forward subluxation of the lens.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: Expired cytotoxic drugs in glass ampules are disposed of in:
questions.solution:
Expired medicines are disposed of in the yellow bag.

All pharmaceutical wastes like antibiotics, cytotoxic drugs including all items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with glass or plastic ampoules, vials, etc. are disposed of in yellow non-chlorinated bags or containers.

Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs to be returned back to the manufacturer or supplier for incineration.
