questions.text: Which of the following shows septate hyphae as depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The microscopic image above shows septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles and a typical conidiophore is characteristic of Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is used for management.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option A: Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image given below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores:

 

Option B: Cryptococcus is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. Microscopy on Gram staining shows gram-positive round budding yeast cells. India ink preparation reveals capsulated budding yeast cells; capsules are prominent in this staining.

The image given below shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained with India ink. Note the prominent capsule.

 

Options C: Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image given below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristic of Paget's disease?
questions.solution:
Paget’s disease is characterized by increased bone turnover with enlargement and thickening of the bone. It is also called osteitis deformans.

It manifests in 4th and 5th-decade males.

The pathologic process in Paget's disease is initiated by overactive osteoclastic bone resorption followed by a compensatory increase in osteoblastic new bone formation. This results in a structurally disorganized mosaic of woven and lamellar bone causing the bones to be unusually brittle. Plasma alkaline phosphatase is increased due to the osteoblastic activity.

questions.text: While examining a man who is accused of rape, you find the presence of smegma on his corona glandis. Which of the following can be inferred from this finding?

choices.text: The person has engaged in sexual act recently
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 24 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 48 hours
The person has not engaged in sexual act in last 1 week

questions.solution:
The presence of smegma on the corona glandis indicates that the person has not engaged in a sexual act in the last 24 hours.

Smegma requires about 24 hours to collect. It gets removed by bathing or washing or intercourse. The absence indicates sexual activity might have been performed in the last 24 hours as it gets rubbed off during intercourse. The presence of smegma absolutely negates the possibility of complete penetration.

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A child with CAH having cortisol deficiency is treated with glucocorticoids. How should the dose of glucocorticoids be altered if this child is undergoing any surgical procedure?

choices.text: Dose should be tapered and stopped
Dose should be doubled or tripled
Glucocorticoids should be withdrawn till Post-operative day 5

questions.solution:
In the above case, Glucocorticoid dose should be doubled or tripled in a child, who is undergoing a surgical procedure.

Cortisol deficiency in CAH is treated with glucocorticoids. Glucocorticoid treatment must be continued indefinitely in all patients with classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency but may not be necessary in patients with the nonclassic disease unless signs of androgen excess are present

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as an infection or surgery. This is because, during periods of stress, the requirement for cortisol is higher.

questions.text: The operating surgeon inserted the following instrument after the exploration of  common bile duct. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr's T tube with the vertical and horizontal limbs.

Kehr's T tube is used after the exploration of common bile duct i.e. horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct and vertical limb is brought out as drain. It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

Common bile duct T-tubes should remain in for 10 days. The 10-day period is required to minimize the risk of biliary peritonitis after removal. However, once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones. some surgeons like to clamp the T-tube prior to removal.

Option B: Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used to provide temporary hemostasis. It causes hemostasis by providing tamponade at the oesophagogastric junction.

Option C: Dobhoff tube is used for providing enteral nutrition.

Option D: Minnesota tube has 4 openings, 2 suction tubes, and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

questions.text: Which of the following undergo co-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is formed by co-translational modification. It is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon.

It is directly incorporated into proteins during the translation process resulting in co-translational modification.

Selenocysteine is seen in the active site of the following enzymes and proteins:

  • Selenoprotein P
  • Iodothyronine deiodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase

All the other 3 options given, undergo post-translational modification.

questions.text: The final length of the hair is determined by the duration of ___________ phase.
questions.solution:
The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest, it is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

Anagen:

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.
  • It can be identified by the presence of angulated root.

Catagen:

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis. Clubbing is first seen in catagen and becomes more prominent in telogen phase.
  • It lasts for about 3 weeks.

Telogen:

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of her hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. What is the preferred management in limiting joint destruction and disability for her?
questions.solution:
The history and image are typical of rheumatoid arthritis. Methotrexate with anti-TNF is preferred in limiting joint destruction and disability.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown etiology characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. A variation in the HLA-DRB1 gene is known to cause RA. Cigarette smoking is known to increase the risk.

Histopathological features include synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation with inflammatory infiltrates and rheumatoid nodules. These are necrotizing granulomas surrounded by fibrinoid necrosis. 

Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness that is relieved with activity. It mainly involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Other hallmark features include flexor tendon tenosynovitis, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity, Z-line deformity, and trigger finger. RA is a systemic disease and leads to a variety of extra-articular manifestations, including fatigue, subcutaneous nodules, interstitial lung disease, etc. 

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis.

Management comprises non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain relief, along with disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs (DMARD). Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice. Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) is given as an adjuvant in combination with other DMARDs. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, anakinra, and rituximab are known to reduce the signs and symptoms of RA, slow the radiographic progression of joint damage, and improve physical function and quality of life.

Combination therapy:

  • Methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (Oral triple therapy).
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide.
  • Methotrexate and a biological such as anti-TNF

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A junior resident, during his first emergency room duty, comes across a patient with difficulty in breathing. Since he was not confident to do endotracheal intubation, he tries to secure the airway with the following device. All of the following are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation, except that _____.

choices.text: It does not require neck mobility.
It is associated with decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration.
It does not require muscle relaxation.
There is no risk of endobronchial intubation.

questions.solution:
This given image is of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). All of the options are the advantages of using this device when compared with tracheal intubation except that it is associated with a decreased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration. There is an increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation: 

Advantages:

  • Less invasive
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: Which of the following does the incidence of post-dural puncture headache not depend on?
questions.solution:
The timing of ambulation does not seem to affect the incidence of post-dural puncture headache, i.e., early ambulation does not increase the incidence.

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The image below shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani.

questions.text: Nitric oxide synthase contributes to the erection of the penis by relaxing the smooth muscle and increasing blood flow by _________

choices.text: Blocking phosphodiesterases to increase cAMP levels
Activating guanylyl cyclases to increase cGMP levels

questions.solution:
Nitric oxide synthase, by synthesising nitric oxide, contributes to the erection of the penis by activating guanylyl cyclases to increase cGMP levels that relax smooth muscle and increase blood flow. 

Nitric Oxide

  • Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF).
  • Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS).
  • Mechanism of action:
    • NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation.
  • Effects of NO:
    • Vasodilation.
    • Neuromodulator in the brain.
    • Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells.
    • In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle
    • Penile erection.

Note:

The drugs like sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), and vardenafil (Levitra) all inhibit the breakdown of cGMP by phosphodiesterases and are used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: What are synovial joints functionally classified as?
questions.solution:
Synovial joints are freely movable joints and therefore functionally classified as diarthrosis. 

Functional classification of joints:

  • Synarthroses - These are immovable. e.g., fibrous joints           
  • Amphiarthroses - They are slightly mobile. e.g., cartilaginous joints 
  • Diarthroses - These are freely mobile. e.g., synovial joints.

questions.text: A microbiologist carries out a milk ring test which gives a blue ring at the top and leaves the milk unstained. Which of the following option is true regarding the most likely organism responsible for this test?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the blue ring at the top and unstained milk is indicative of A positive Milk Ring Test (MRT). The most likely organism giving positive MRT is Brucella species. They are Non-motile and aerobic.

Features of Brucellae:

  • They are non-motile, non-capsulated, and non-sporing. They are Gram-negative and non-acid fast.
  • They are strict aerobes
  • They are catalase-positive, oxidase-positive (except for B.neotomae and B.ovis which are negative) and urease positive. Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. MR and VP tests are negative

Milk Ring Test:

  •  It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy, farms, etc. 
  • A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.
  • If antibodies are present in the milk the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: In a patient with suspected Behcet's disease which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pathergy test can be used for confirming Behcet's disease. It is a nonspecific inflammatory skin reaction to scratch or intradermal saline injection and is a specific manifestation. 

The diagnostic criteria in Behcet's syndrome are the presence of recurrent oral ulcerations plus two of the following findings:

  • Recurrent genital ulcerations
  • Ocular lesions
  • Skin lesions
  • Positive pathergy test

Option A: Foshay test is used in cat-scratch disease.

Option B: Tzanck test is used to diagnose herpes infection.

Option D: The cardiolipin antibody test is used to detect antiphospholipid antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following acts to increase the release of calcium ions from the endoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
In response to a stimulus, the efflux of calcium from intracellular stores occurs through an Inositol triphosphate receptor (IP3R)- Ca+2 channel.

The source of Ca+2 in smooth muscle contraction can be different depending on the activating stimulus.

  • The influx from the extracellular site through voltage or ligand-gated Ca+2 channels in the plasma membrane
  • Efflux from intracellular stores (eg, sarcoplasmic reticulum) through the RyR and the inositol triosephosphate receptor (IP3R).

questions.text:
A 32 year old man presents to the casualty with complaints of severe left great toe pain; He has had no such prior episodes. A picture of his left foot is shown below. 
On performing an X- Ray which of the following do you expect to see?

choices.text: Martel’s Sign/ G Sign/ Rat Bite Erosions

questions.solution:
Only Soft - Tissue Swelling will be present in the X Ray of a person with Acute attack of Gout.

The history clearly says he has had no prior episodes and the clinical presentation is that of a clear cut acute attack.

The image shows inflamed great toe consistent with the above. In acute attack only soft tissue swelling will be seen in the x ray.

The other options, Martel’s Sign/ G Sign, Rat Bite Erosion, Joint space narrowing, Secondary Osteoarthritis are all characteristic of chronic gout.

questions.text: The second most common site for the hematogenous spread of breast carcinoma is ______
questions.solution:
The femur is the second most common site for the hematogenous spread of carcinoma breast. These bone metastases are more osteolytic than osteoblastic.

Order of hematogenous spread of carcinoma breast from most common sites are as follows:

  • L= Lumbar vertebrae (Most common site)
  • F= Femur
  • T= Thoracic vertebrae
  • R= Ribs
  • S= Skull

 

Note: In prostate cancer, the bone metastases are more osteoblastic than osteolytic.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a cochlear implant is brought to the emergency room after he met with a road traffic accident. Which among the following investigations is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in this patient with a cochlear implant.

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields. Ferromagnetic objects when near a magnet experience a force of attraction towards the magnet bore and fatalities have occurred because of this. Most cochlear implants, cardiac pacemakers, and intracranial aneurysm clips contraindicate entry to the MRI room.

MRI is contraindicated in patients with:

  • Cardiac pacemakers
  • Metallic foreign body
  • Cochlear implants or neural stimulators
  • Vascular clips
  • Claustrophobia (relative contraindication)

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy while playing football had an injury to the right knee. Following which, he developed swelling in the same knee within 2 hours due to hemarthrosis. Which of the following ligament tear is the common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Anterior cruciate ligament tear is the common cause of hemarthrosis.

The duration of the swelling following trauma gives a clue to the probable diagnosis,

  • If a swelling develops within 2 hours of the injury, it suggests hemarthrosis
  • If it develops after 2 to 24 hours, it suggests traumatic synovitis.

Approximately 75% of the cases of hemarthrosis are due to anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tears.

questions.text: During routine USG examination of a G2P1L1 woman, you note findings suggestive of placenta increta. What is the pathology involved in this condition?

choices.text: Villi are attached to lower uterine segment

questions.solution:
In placenta increta, the chorionic villi invade the myometrium.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. These occur due to:

  • Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 
  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

The various types of morbidly adherent placenta are:

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

 

Note: Villi are attached to the lower uterine segment in placenta previa.

 

Investigations that help in diagnosing these conditions:

  • USG
  • Color Doppler 
  • MRI 

 

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

 

The image below shows placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female presents with complaints of fatigue and severe itching throughout her body. On investigation, serum GGT and ALP levels were found to be elevated with a mild elevation in AST and ALT levels. The histopathological image of her liver biopsy is given below. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be present in this patient?

GGT- Gamma glutamyl transferase
ALP- Alkaline phosphatase
AST- Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT- Alanine aminotransferase

choices.text: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture with the presence of florid duct lesions on histopathology is indicative of primary biliary cholangitis. The antibodies most likely to be present in PBC are anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA).

Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition characterized by portal inflammation and necrosis of cholangiocytes in small and medium-sized bile ducts. It has a strong female preponderance with a median age of 50 years.

The most common symptoms include fatigue that is out of proportion to the severity of the liver disease or the patient's age and pruritus, which is usually most bothersome in the evening. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease, including hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, ascites, and edema are found to be present.

Amond the liver enzymes, GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. The majority of the patients show anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) positive. A liver biopsy shows a florid duct lesion. This occurs due to the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation.

Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with decompensated cirrhosis due to PBC. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line drug that helps to slow down the rate of progression of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Anti Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody (ANCA) is seen in autoimmune vasculitis.

Option B: Antibodies to Liver Kidney microsomes type 1 (anti-LKM1) are characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis.

Option D: Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) may be seen in PBC, but the most common is an Anti-Mitochondrial Antibody (A). AМΑ is the serologic hallmark of PBC. It is present in approximately 95 percent of patients with ΡBС. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are found in up to 70 percent of patients with РBC.

Related Pearl: Differences between primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and primary biliary cholangitis (PBC)

  Primary Biliary Cholangitis Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis
Antibodies

Antimitochondrial antibodies positive in most patients

Antinuclear antibodies positive

Antimitochondrial antibodies /AMA typically negative

p-ANCA-positive
Age group 40–60 years 30-45 years
Gender predominance Females Males
Site Intrahepatic bile ducts only Intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
 Associated with

Sjogren syndrome

CREST syndrome

Rheumatoid arthritis

Celiac disease

questions.text: A patient presents with discrete thyroid swelling and FNAC was done.  In order to suspect malignancy of this thyroid swelling, the FNAC report should correspond to _________
questions.solution:
In order to suspect malignancy of this thyroid swelling, the FNAC report should correspond to Thy 4.

Classification of fine- needle aspiration cytology reports

Type Meaning
Thy 1 Non diagnostic
Thy 1c Non diagnostic cystic
Thy 2 Non neoplastic
Thy 3 Follicular
Thy 4 Suspicious of malignancy
Thy 5 Malignancy

questions.text: A senior resident during his ward rounds advises the intern to replace the cannula of a patient. The intern uses the cannula as shown in the image below. What is the gauge of this cannula?
questions.solution:
The given cannula is 17 gauge IV cannula as its color code is white.

The flow rate in cannula of this gauge is 125mL/minute.

questions.text: The materials to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning during an autopsy include:

choices.text: Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, brain
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, heart, lungs
Stomach, small intestine, liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood and urine

questions.solution:
Viscera to be preserved routinely in every case of poisoning include; stomach and proximal 30 cm of small intestine with their contents, 500 gms liver with gall bladder, kidney, blood (25 ml) and urine sample.

Special viscera (To be preserved along with routine viscera):

  • Brain is also to be preserved in cases of volatile and other CNS poisons.
  • Spinal cord should be preserved in case of strychnine and gelsemium poisoning.
  • Half of each lungs or one whole lung should be preserved in case of inhaled poisons.
  • Entire heart should be preserved in cases of cardiac poisoning, arsenic poisoning etc.
  • Bones, and scalp hairs are preserved in heavy metal poisoning.
  • Nails can be preserved in arsenic poisoning. 

A saturated salt solution is used commonly for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Rectified spirit is indicated for most of the poisons, exceptions being alcohol, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, carbolic acid, acetic acid, etc.

questions.text: Rose thorn appearance on barium study is seen in ________
questions.solution:
Rose thorn appearance/rose thorn ulcers are seen in Crohn's disease.

It refers to the deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissuring typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. They appear as thorn-like extraluminal projections on barium studies

Coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space) is the characteristic finding seen in Barium enema X-ray in a case of intussusception.

Sawtooth appearance on barium enema is seen in colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: This is a picture of the female vulva. What is the homologous male structure marked X?
questions.solution:
The structure marked X in the image is labia minora. The ventral aspect of the penis (penile urethra) is a male homologue of female labia minora.

The vulva includes mons veneris, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, vestibule, and perineum.

The vulva is the collective name for external genitalia and perineum.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased.

Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffian duct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective sperm transport resulting in obstructive azoospermia.

The sexual function is generally unimpaired.

Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (≥60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport. 

Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.

Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

questions.text: An IV urogram of a child who presented with recurrent urinary tract infection is shown below. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: The upper pole ureter inserts superolaterally in the bladder
The lower pole ureter may lead to vesicoureteral reflux
The upper pole ureter is usually obstructed
The lower pole ureter inserts into the bladder through a shorter submucosal tunnel

questions.solution:
The given scenario with the image of the intravenous urogram showing the "drooping lily" sign is suggestive of a completely duplicated collecting system. According to Weigert Meyer's rule of complete duplication of the ureter, the ureter draining from the upper pole of the kidney enters the bladder medial and inferior to the ureter draining from the lower pole.

This is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract which occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

There are 2 types of duplication:

  1. Incomplete- Y ureter arises when the ureteric bud bifurcates after its initial development from the mesonephric duct
  2. Complete- 2 separate ureteric buds. One is at normal while the second one is at a lower position. The lower pole ureter is associated with vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) due to its insertion into the bladder through a short submucosal tunnel. The upper pole ureter commonly gets in obstructed resulting in scarring.

Often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. If the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and it looks like a drooping lily. 

The condition is asymptomatic in adults while children have VUR. Females are more commonly affected. Voiding is normal but prolonged dribbling of urine is seen.

According to Weigart Meyer's rule of congenital complete duplication of the ureter:

  • The ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney (Weigert–Meyer rule). The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 
  • In case of an incomplete duplication, there is only one ureteric orifice on that side of the bladder.

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty. Other options include a partial or complete nephrectomy.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A second-year medical student, during the ward rounds, asks one of the patients to keep his fingers as shown in the image, to elicit a clinical finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The medical student, by asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed, is trying to elicit clubbing. Irritable bowel syndrome is not associated with clubbing.

In a normal person, when the dorsal surfaces of the distal parts of two fingers are opposed, a diamond-shaped gap is created, called Schamroth's window. 

Obliteration in clubbed fingers of the diamond-shaped window normally produced is called the Schamroth's sign.


Clubbing is the growth of the tips of the fingers which occurs due to connective tissue proliferation. It can be idiopathic, hereditary, or acquired.

The underlying mechanism for clubbing is still unclear but different hypotheses include anoxic, toxic, neurogenic, metabolic, and humoral. 

The different grades of clubbing are as follows: 

Grade 1 Increased fluctuation of the nail bed with loss of onychodermal angle
Grade 2 

Increase in antero-posterior and transverse diameter of the nails. Nails becomes smooth and glossy with loss of longitudinal ridges.
Grade 3

Increased pulp tissue
Grade 4

Wrist and ankle swelling due to hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Causes of clubbing include: 

  1. Cardiac causes
    1. Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    2. Subacute bacterial endocarditis
    3. Cardiac tumors
    4. Eisenmenger's syndrome
  2. Lung and pleural causes
    1. Bronchiectasis
    2. Lung abscess
    3. Bronchogenic carcinoma
    4. Empyema thoracis
    5. Fibrosing alveolitis
    6. Pleural mesothelioma
    7. Pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
    8. Cystic fibrosis
    9. Fibrocaseous tuberculosis
  3. Ulcerative colitis
  4. Biliary cirrhosis
  5. Intestinal causes
    1. Malabsorption
    2. Crohn's disease
    3. Polyposis coli
    4. Coeliac disease
  6. Normal
  7. Genetic

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

Nail finding

Clubbing

  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding Euchromatin?

choices.text: Transcriptionally inactive and  less densely packed
Transcriptionally active and  less densely packed

questions.solution:
Euchromatin is Transcriptionally active and less densely packed.

Differences between heterochromatin and euchromatin:

Heterochromatin Euchromatin
Transcriptionally inactive Transcriptionally active
Densely packed Less densely packed
Chromatin stains densely Chromatin stains less densely
The chromatin in the region is high in meC content (methylation of deoxycytidine residues which decrease gene transcription)  Generally replicated earlier than heterochromatin
Histone deacetylation increases heterochromatin Histone acetylation increases euchromatin

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the last 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. Which of the following can you use to treat her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana.  A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.

The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated salt solution and are non-bile stained.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children and is usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

questions.text: A pregnant sportswoman comes to you seeking advice regarding calorie intake. She says her routine involves heavy work. What would be the net energy requirement per day in her case?
questions.solution:
A woman doing heavy work requires 2720 kcal and in pregnancy, an additional 350 kcal is needed.

Hence, the total requirement for a heavily working pregnant woman is 3070 kcal.

  • Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group
  • Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has complaints of marked dryness in her mouth associated with difficulty in swallowing. Schirmer's test is suggestive of severe dry eye. An immunoassay shows the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies. Which of the following types of renal tubular acidosis is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms together with the presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B antibodies are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome. Type 1 (distal) RTA can be seen in this patient.

The causes of type 1 RTA are as follows

Primary

  • Sporadic
  • Inherited (autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive)

Secondary

  • Systemic genetic diseases such as osteoporosis, elliptocytosis, Ehler-Danlos syndrome, Primary hyperoxaluria type 2
  • Acquired conditions such as
    • Autoimmune diseases: Sjogren's syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, hyperglobulinemia
    • Renal transplantation
    • Medullary sponge kidney
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Malnutrition
    • Drugs and toxics - amphotericin B, lithium salts, amiloride, toluene

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is diagnosed with an impulse control disorder characterized by an obsession to set fire to things. All of the following disorders may be seen as an associated disorder in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the condition known as Pyromania, which is associated with all the above-mentioned options except schizophrenia.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is suspected to have Cushing's syndrome. Which of the following investigations is not performed until a confirmatory diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established?

choices.text: Measurement of 24 hours urinary free cortisol

questions.solution:
The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is done only after a diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established in a patient.

The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used in patients with confirmed Cushing syndrome. It helps to differentiate between Cushing's disease (i.e a pituitary cause) and ectopic ACTH production.

The basis for this test is that in subjects with Cushing disease, a higher dose of dexamethasone (usually 8 mg) is required to suppress ACTH secretion and drop cortisol levels in serum, urine, and saliva.

Standard 2-day (high dose) dexamethasone suppression test:

  • Serum cortisol level and/or 24-hour urinary free cortisol is measured as a baseline, and then dexamethasone 2 mg orally is taken every 6 hours for 48 hours; urine for free cortisol is collected during the test, and serum cortisol is checked 6 hours after the last dose. The suppression of cortisol secretion to >50 % of the baseline is considered positive and indicative of Cushing's disease

The following four investigations are used to establish an initial diagnosis of endogenous Cushing's syndrome as per the clinical guidelines of the endocrine society.

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol (increased 3x above normal)
  • Midnight salivary cortisol ( >5nmol/L)
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression (plasma cortisol >50 nmol/L at 8-9 AM after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 PM)
  • Standard 2-day (low dose) dexamethasone suppression test (plasma cortisol > 50 nmol/L after 0.5 mg dexamethasone 6th hourly for 48 hours).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was diagnosed with AIDS and was started on antiretroviral drugs. After 10 months patient came to OPD and examination revealed hands as shown. The following change is encountered with the use of which of the following antiretroviral agents?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Nail hyperpigmentation which is commonly encountered with the use of zidovudine. This is seen with chronic zidovudine administration. 

The adverse effects of Zidovudine are:

  • Fatigue, malaise, myalgia, anorexia, headache, insomnia
  • Erythrocytic macrocytosis
  • Nail hyperpigmentation
  • Myopathy
  • Bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and granulocytopenia 

The image below shows zidovudine induced nail hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented to a general physician with complaints of difficulty in breathing even with mild activities for the past 1 month. He has a chronic history of smoking with an estimated toll of 20 pack-years. Auscultation of the chest shows extensive, bilateral wheeze and crepitations. The HRCT of the chest is given below. Which of the following measures is least likely to improve the survival benefit in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Inhaled corticosteroids are least likely to improve the survival benefit in these patients.

The given CT image shows extensive emphysematous changes in the bilateral lungs.

Only the following three interventions have been demonstrated to improve the survival benefit in COPD patients.

  • Smoking cessation
  • Oxygen therapy in chronically hypoxemic patients
  • Lung volume reduction surgery in selected patients with emphysema.

questions.text: All of the following are protective factors for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) except _________
questions.solution:
IUCD users are a risk factor for PID and not a protective factor.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

Note: Several studies in developed and developing countries have found that current or recent OC use reduces the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, a major cause of female infertility. These studies have found that OC use lowers the risk by, on average, about 40 percent. Two mechanisms may be operative:

  • OCs may change the cervical mucus such that it prevents pathogenic organisms from ascending into the upper genital tract; or
  • OCs reduce menstrual blood flow, thus decreasing the amount of medium available for bacterial growth.

questions.text: One urban primary health center is functional for a population of:
questions.solution:
One urban primary health center (U-PHC) is functional for a population of 50,000-60,000.

An urban primary health center will be staffed with two doctors (one regular and one on a part-time basis): 3 staff nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 lady health visitor, and 3–5 ANMs (depending upon the population covered). It may be located preferably within a slum or near a slum.

One U-PHC will cover a population of around 50,000 to 60,000. Basic functions will include

  • Outpatient department consultations
  • Basic lab diagnosis
  • Drug/contraceptive dispensing
  • Health education
  • Referral services.

It does not include in-patient care.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution: 

HWC-PHC HWC-UPHC 24X7 HWC-PHC/UPHC
Essential: 2 beds Essential: 2 daycare beds Essential: 6 beds
Desirable: +4 beds Desirable: +4 daycare beds Desirable: +4 beds

Note: The desirable will be over and above the essential beds.

The twelve packages envisaged under Comprehensive Primary Healthcare services (CPHC): 

  1. Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth 
  2. Neonatal and Infant Health Care Services
  3. Childhood and Adolescent Health Care Services
  4. Family Planning, Contraceptive Services, and other Reproductive Health Care Services
  5. Management of Communicable Diseases: National Health Programmes
  6. General Out-patient Care for Acute Simple Illnesses and Minor Ailments
  7. Screening, Prevention, Control and Management of Non-communicable Diseases
  8. Care for Common Ophthalmic and ENT Problems
  9. Basic Oral Health Care
  10. Elderly and Palliative Health Care Services
  11. Emergency Medical Services including Burns and Trauma
  12. Screening and Basic Management of Mental Health Ailments.

IPHS 2022 normal for manpower at PHC:

Essential manpower for:

1) PHC: 12   2) UPHC: 16   3) Polyclinic: 22   4) 24x7 PHC: 23   5) 24X7 UPHC: 27

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: An MBBS student, after attending a class on genetic disorders, noticed that a particular disorder appears in three consecutive generations of his family without any sex predilection. While drawing his pedigree chart, it also struck him that phenotypically normal family members were having healthy offspring. Based on this information, he concluded the pattern of inheritance of this disorder. What is the correct pattern?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance in this genetic disorder is autosomal dominant.

Points in favour:

  • Autosomal dominant disorders have a vertical mode of transmission (individuals of two generations are affected—parent and children affected).
  • It appears in three consecutive generations of a family without any sex predilection.
  • An affected individual has a 50% chance of passing on the deleterious gene in each pregnancy.
  • Males and females are equally affected.
  • Unaffected individuals do not pass on the disorder to their children.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with pruritis which worsens particularly on undressing at night. On examination, his skin is found to be dry and a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern is observed on the legs. This patient is suffering from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Asteatotic eczema.

  • Asteatotic eczema usually develops in elderly patients.
  • Asteatotic eczema affects the legs, arms, and hands of elderly people in the context of very dry skin.
  • A characteristic crazy-paving pattern is observed on the legs, in particular, resulting in the synonym of eczema craquele.
  • It is also called as Winter eczema.
  • Irritation in this form of eczema is often intense, and worse with changes in temperature, particularly on undressing at night.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with tall stature, frontal bossing, prognathism, large hands, and feet is started on a growth hormone receptor antagonist. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts acromegaly. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist that is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

Octreotide and lanreotide are synthetic somatostatin analogs that can be used in the management of acromegaly.

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist used primarily to treat hyperprolactinemia also has an indication in the management of acromegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma drugs is approved for the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis?
questions.solution:
Bimatoprost is an antiglaucoma drug approved for topical application in the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis (the presence of less than the normal amount of hair).

Bimatoprost is a PGF-2 alpha analog. PGF-2 alpha analogs are associated with eyelash hypertrichosis; hence, it is used in hypotrichosis of the eyelashes. Bimatoprost is also used in the treatment of ocular hypertension and open-angle glaucoma.

Adverse effects of bimatoprost include iris and eyelid pigmentation; it can also cause upper respiratory tract infection in about 10% of patients.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Lid retraction

Macular edema

Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)

questions.text: A 4 months-old male child was brought to the hospital with the complaints of a lesion in the abdomen as shown in the image. The drug used for the treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows flat to elevated, irregular, red-blue masses in the skin of the abdomen suggestive of hemangioma. Propranolol is the preferred treatment of infantile hemangioma.

It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis, and inhibiting angiogenesis. Propranolol at 2 mg/kg/day has been found useful in infants younger than 6 months and children up to 5 years of age. 

Complications of infantile hemangioma include pain, functional impairment, or permanent disfigurement.

Timolol is also used in the treatment of infantile hemangioma.

Other options:

Options B, C, D: Bisoprolol, acebutolol, and atenolol are cardioselective beta-blockers that are not used in the treatment of hemangioma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tonic receptor?
questions.solution:
Ruffini's end organs are tonic (slowly adapting) receptors.

Pacinian corpuscles, Meissner's corpuscles, and hair end-organ are phasic (rapidly adapting) receptors.

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: Project MONICA was managed under:
questions.solution:
WHO has completed a project known as MONICA, it is related to cardiovascular diseases. It stands for the multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries. 26 countries were participating in this project, which was planned to continue for a 10 year period ending in 1994.

This project specifically focussed on trends in event rates for coronary heart attacks and strokes, and on trends in cardiovascular risk factors ( blood pressure, cigarette smoking and serum cholesterol) in men and women aged 25-64 in the same defined communities.

The WHO MONICA project has without any doubt significantly contributed to global prevention efforts. The MONICA methodology is increasingly used as a measurement tool for cardiovascular and non-communicable disease prevention and control programs.

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease, who is currently on dialysis has the following skin lesion on her abdomen. Which of the following hormones can be attributed to this?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding in the given image is 'calciphylaxis'. It is associated with hyperparathyroidism or an elevated calcium product.

Pathogenesis: There is an imbalance of inhibitors and inducers of vascular calcification. This results in excessive calcium deposition in medium-sized arteries, which further leads to necrosis of the part supplied by that vessel.

It commonly affects the fatty areas of thighs, abdomen, and buttocks symmetrically. The lesion evolves from purpura to a black eschar.

Management:

  • Supportive and preventive measures including hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • Debridement and wound care
  • Antibiotics
  • Parathyroidectomy
  • Cinacalcet and phosphate binders
  • Intravenous sodium thiosulphate

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the toxin produced by most common organism implicated in the causation of traveler’s diarrhea?

choices.text: Heat stable-A (ST-A) toxin insoluble in methanol
Heat stable-B (ST-B) toxin is soluble in methanol

questions.solution:
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is the most common organism implicated in the causation of traveler’s diarrhea and Heat stable-A (ST-A) toxin acts by ↑cGMP is the correct option.

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is toxigenic, but not invasive. Toxins produced includes, 

  • LT (heat-labile toxin): acts by ↑cAMP
  • ST (heat-stable toxin): Two types of ST are known, ST-A (or ST I, which is soluble in methanol) and ST-B (or ST-II, insoluble in methanol).
    • ST-A acts by ↑cGMP  in the intestine
    • ST-B: Its mode of action is not known though it is not through cAMP or cGMP.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with pain abdomen. On per abdominal examination, there is guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with purulent peritonitis.  What is Hinchey's stage in this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis belongs to stage 3 in the Hinchey staging system.

Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis:

Stage 1

 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

 Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

 Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis

The modified Hinchey classification is the most commonly used tool to describe the severity of diverticulitis. The ability of a CT scan to distinguish between grade 3 and grade 4 is limited. An accurate diagnosis is made in the operating room. The Modified Hinchey classification system is as follows:

Stage 0

 Mild clinical diverticulitis

Stage 1a 

 Confined pericolic inflammation—phlegmon

Stage 1b

 Confined pericolic abscess (within sigmoid mesocolon)

Stage 2

 Pelvic, distant intraabdominal, or intraperitoneal abscess

Stage 3 

 Generalized purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis

questions.text: MGIT(Mycobacteria Growth Indicator Tube) has an additional advantage of finding mycobacterial resistance to which of the following anti-tubercular drugs in comparison with the BacT Alert method?
questions.solution:
BACTEC MGIT has an additional advantage of finding mycobacterial resistance to Pyrazinamide drug, wherein the BactALERT method cannot detect resistance to this drug.

BACTEC MGIT: 

  • It is a rapid growth detection method, which uses 7H9 Middlebrook medium with fluorometric detection technology via oxygen consumption.
  • An added advantage is that the incorporation of Pyrazinamide (PZA) in the medium detects resistance to this drug

BacT Alert:

  • This method uses colorimetric method of growth detection, due to the production of CO2 as a result of bacterial metabolism during growth. 
  • This method can be used to test streptomycin, isoniazid, rifampicin, and ethambutol (SIRE), while MGIT is used to test these same drugs plus Pyrazinamide.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female diagnosed with cerebral venous thrombosis is admitted in the intensive care unit for the past 7 days. She is being treated with intravenous, unfractionated heparin since her admission. On day 7, she developed multiple areas of skin necrosis. Lab reports show a platelet count of 75,000/μL and positive serotonin release assay. Which of the following group of drugs is approved by the US-FDA for preventing thrombosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The female patient in this clinical scenario is likely to suffer from Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT). Direct thrombin inhibitors such as lepirudin, argatroban, and bivalirudin are approved by the US-FDA for the prevention of thrombosis in patients with HIT

HIT is commonly diagnosed clinically by means of 4T scoring (Thrombocytopenia, Timing of platelet count fall, Thrombosis, Other causes for Thrombocytopenia)

HIT is an allergic reaction with at least a 50% drop in platelet count after the start of heparin causing venous and arterial thrombosis.

Clinical features of HIT are:

Features Description
Thrombocytopenia Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in
platelet count of ≥50%
Timing Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting
heparin
Type of heparin unfractionated heparin > LMWH
Type of patient

Females > Males,                    Surgical /cancer patients > medical
Thrombosis Venous thrombosis > Arterial

Enzyme-linked assays such as Platelet activation assay and Heparin-PF-4 complex antibody assay are sensitive but not specific for HIT. Serotonin release assay is the most specific test for the diagnosis of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a dermatophytic infection. A scraping from the lesion was observed under the potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount. It revealed the macroconidia of the dermatophyte as shown in the image below. The species of this genera usually infects:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing spindle-shaped macroconidia point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection. The species of this genera usually infect skin and hair.

Dermatophytes involve only the superficial keratinized layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment. How will you stage the disease?
questions.solution:
Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). 

The clinical staging of ROP is as follows:

  • Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge 
  • Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
  • Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- Total retinal detachment

questions.text: Which of the following anterior pituitary hormones share a common Alpha(α) subunit that is the product of a single gene?
questions.solution:
FSH, LH, and TSH hormones of anterior pituitary share a common Alpha(α) subunit.

Five types of secretory cells have been identified in the anterior pituitary. They are

  • Somatotropes: which secrete growth hormone
  • Lactotropes (also called mammotropes): which secrete prolactin
  • Corticotropes: which secrete ACTH
  • Thyrotropes: which secrete TSH
  • Gonadotropes: which secrete FSH and LH.

It is notable that the three pituitary glycoprotein hormones i.e FSH, LH, and TSH while being made up of two subunits, all share a common α subunit that is the product of a single gene and has the same amino acid composition in each hormone, although their carbohydrate residues vary. 

The α subunit must be combined with the β subunit characteristic of each hormone for maximal physiologic activity.

questions.text: Best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus is  _____
questions.solution:
Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV US) is the best investigation to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus. It is recommended as the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour, so it cannot distinguish between fusion (didelphys and bicornuate) and reabsorption (septate and arcuate) uterine anomalies.

Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV US is not possible, like virgins.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would not be seen in a patient with SIADH?
questions.solution:
In a patient with (SIADH) syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone, increased plasma renin activity would not be seen. Plasma renin activity is suppressed in SIADH.

In SIADH, there is a failure of the body to increase the diuresis even when the water intake is more than the urinary loss. There is a slight increase in the total body water. This causes dilutional euvolemic hyponatremia and reduced serum osmolality (Option C). This causes a suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) (Option D) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels are increased because of excess fluid retention. Suppressed RAAS and increased ANP and BNP together work to minimise the increase in extracellular volume and prevent oedema by increasing the GFR (Option B). They also cause increased sodium excretion in the urine.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH
