questions.text: A 32-year-old working woman is pregnant, she already has 2 surviving children. According to the Maternity Act 2017, what duration of paid leave would she receive?
questions.solution:
According to Maternity Act 2017, a working mother who already has 2 surviving children will be given a paid leave for a maximum duration of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks precedes the expected date of delivery.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text:
What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale
questions.solution:
The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario is 7.

It is calculated as follows:

  • Opening of the eyes to a painful stimulus - 2
  • Incomprehensible sounds - 2
  • Decorticate posturing/ abnormal flexion  - 3 

In the decorticate posture, elbows, wrists, and fingers are flexed, and the legs are extended and rotated inward, as seen in the image.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess patients with a head injury.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who visited North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to North America suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces fungi. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B- Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis. Infection is acquired by inhalation. Most infections are asymptomatic but infection of the reticuloendothelial system manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia and it is highly fatal. 

Option C- Coccidiodes immitis is also a dimorphic fungus causing coccidiomycosis. Infection is acquired through inhalation of dust-containing spores of the fungus. Mostly they are asymptomatic and a self-limiting influenza-like fever termed valley fever or desert rheumatism develops in some individuals. The infection leads to lifetime immunity. 

Option D- Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is again a dimorphic fungus causing paracoccidioidomycosis also termed South American blastomycosis. Infection is initially acquired by the inhalation of spores causing primary pulmonary infection. It spreads to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics by hematogenous spread resulting in ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa. 

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: A microbiologist while doing research about in-vitro anaphylaxis noticed vigorous contraction of isolated tissues, such as intestinal and uterine muscle strips from sensitized guinea pig held in a bath of Ringer's solution when a specific antigen is added to the bath. All of the following are the secondary mediators involved in the hypersensitivity reaction seen in this phenomenon except _______
questions.solution:
The Phenomenon noticed by the microbiologist is the Schultz–Dale phenomenon, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction. Serotonin is a primary mediator involved in this reaction, not secondary.

  • Schultz–Dale phenomenon is a phenomenon where isolated tissues, such as intestinal or uterine muscle strips from sensitized guinea pigs if held in a bath or Ringer’s solution they contract vigorously on addition of specific antigen to the bath. It is an example of Anaphylaxis in-vitro.
  • This phenomenon is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Primary mediators are the preformed contents of mast cells and basophils. It includes Histamine, Serotonin, Chemotactic factors and Enzymatic mediators such as proteases and hydrolases.
  • Secondary mediators are newly formed upon stimulation by mast cells , basophils and other leucocytes. It includes Prostaglandins, leukotrienes and Platelet-activating factor.

questions.text: After initiation of levodopa therapy, a 55-year-old patient starts experiencing adverse effects. Which of these side effects is not decreased by the addition of carbidopa?
questions.solution:
Behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, delusions, postural hypotension are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa.

In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.

The combination of levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors like carbidopa inhibits peripheral adverse effects of dopamine. This decreases the adverse effects like:

  • Anorexia, nausea, and vomiting 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • On and off effect of motor performance

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

choices.text: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when the  pH of water is around seven
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.solution:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH  around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection.

Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water.

Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses.

Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a lump in the right breast. On clinical examination, there was no lymphadenopathy and the surgeon decided to do the following procedure shown in the image. What is the recommended site of injection for the radioisotope-labeled albumin for doing this procedure?

choices.text: Subcutaneously in axilla and around lump

questions.solution:
The following image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera and the recommended site of injection of radioisotope-labelled albumin is the subdermal plexus around the nipple.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. This procedure is done only on node-negative tumors.

  • Technique: methylene blue dye or radioisotope (technetium)-labelled albumin is injected in subdermal plexus around the nipple. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node using a gamma camera.
  • The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for the identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed.
  • The combination of blue dye and technetium-labelled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman is on anti-arrhythmic drugs after she had ventricular fibrillation 3 months back. During her routine diabetic checkup, the ophthalmological examination shows corneal findings as in the image. This is due to the use of ____________
questions.solution:
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines, as shown in the above image, is called corneal verticillata. Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of amiodarone.

Other causes of corneal verticillata: 

  • Fabry’s disease
  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine
  • Hydroxychloroquine
  • Indomethacin
  • Phenothiazines.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic used in the management of resistant VT and recurrent VF and is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed. It causes rapid termination of such arrhythmias when administered IV. Adverse effects include pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, thyroid disorders, photodermatitis, and corneal deposits. 

Adverse effects of amiodarone:

  • Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on IV injection and after drug cumulation
  • Photosensitization
  • Corneal microdeposits -corneal verticillata
  • Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Goitre, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism

questions.text: Fibrous ankylosis follows tuberculosis of all the following except:
questions.solution: Tuberculosis of joints everywhere else in the body results only in fibrous ankylosis except in the spine where it causes bony ankylosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male consumes alcohol by his own will from a bar. When he returns home, his father questions him regarding his alcohol addiction. The man gets agitated and assaults his father. Which among the following IPC sections render the son responsible for his actions?
questions.solution:
In this situation, the son is responsible for his actions according to IPC section 86.

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act according to IPC section 86.

IPC Section 84 states that the act of a person of an unsound mind is not liable for punishment/prosecution. Also, known as the McNaughten's Rule, the IPC states that, ''Nothing is an offense which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law''. 

The defense under this section requires the following elements to be established:

(i) The accused was suffering from unsoundness of mind at the time of doing the act.

(ii) The accused was incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that he was doing what was either wrong or contrary to law.

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

-

A child under 7 years is not liable for the act.

21

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

McNaughten's rule: A person of unsound mind is not liable for the act.

23

24

questions.text: A first-year MBBS student came to OPD with intermittent episodes of a feeling of impending doom accompanied by intense perspiration. Usually, the episodes occur prior to her exams. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is panic disorder.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort. Recurrent panic attacks for more than one month is classified as panic disorder.

Panic attacks can occur in mental disorders other than panic disorder, particu­larly in specific phobia, social phobia, and PTSD.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a demographic process?
questions.solution:
Morbidity is not a demographic process.

Demography refers to the study of the population. Demographic processes include:

  • Fertility
  • Mortality
  • Marriage
  • Migration
  • Social mobility

These processes continuously bring about changes in the population size, composition, and distribution.

questions.text: What is the earliest sonographic sign for the condition in which large amounts of fluid build up in two or more body areas of a fetus?
questions.solution:
The condition in which large amounts of fluid build up in two or more body areas of a fetus along with placental thickning is hydrops fetalis and the earliest sign in hydrops is scalp edema / Subcutaneous edema also known as Halo sign.

Other USG signs include:

  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Subcutaneous edema/scalp edema also known as Halosign
  • Typical position termed as Buddha's position

questions.text: During a pandemic of influenza a drug that inhibits the elution process of the virus was used. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Oseltamivir is a viral neuraminidase inhibitor that inhibits the elution process of the virus.

Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface. This occurs due to neuraminidase (NA) which is present on the surface of the influenza virus. (Influenza contains two surface antigens HA and NA). Neuraminidase destroys the receptor which is used for binding. Hence, it is also called a receptor destroying enzyme (RDE). Oseltamivir inhibits neuraminidase activity and leads to viral aggregation at the cell surface and reduced virus spread within the respiratory epithelium. 

Options A and D: Interference with the M2 protein of influenza virus is seen with amantadine and rimantadine.

Option C: The endonuclease inhibitor for the treatment of acute uncomplicated influenza in adults is baloxavir marboxil.

questions.text: A 58-year-old white man presents with a 6-month history of productive cough, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. HRCT shows a cluster of grapes appearance. A biopsy shows features of a non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection. Cystic fibrosis is ruled out. Which of the following drugs is not to be used in the treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to a non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) infection. Mucolytic dornase is recommended routinely in cystic fibrosis (CF)-related bronchiectasis but not in non-CF bronchiectasis.

Macrolides (azithromycin or clarithromycin) combined with rifampicin and ethambutol are used in the treatment of non-CF bronchiectasis.

Treatment of bronchiectasis:

  1. Antibiotic therapy: This is used to treat exacerbations and is given for 10-14 days. Commonly administered antibiotics include:
    • Amoxicillin or clarithromycin: First-line drugs
    • Ciprofloxacin: For Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  2. Airway clearance:
    • Postural drainage: This is done by gravity-assisted positioning of the patient and chest physiotherapy.
    • Mucolytic treatment: only in cystic fibrosis patients 
      • Normal or hypertonic saline (≥3%) nebulization
      • Humidified air inhalation
      • Drugs like N-acetylcysteine or carbocysteine
  3. Others:
    • Inhaled bronchodilators like long-acting β2 agonists and anticholinergics
    • Long-term oxygen therapy: In patients with chronic respiratory failure
    • Pulmonary rehabilitation
    • Adequate hydration
    • Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation: In refractory cases

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is a part of the special somatic afferent column?
questions.solution:
Vestibulocochlear nerve nucleus is a part of the special somatic afferent column. It is a pure sensory nerve that is responsible for hearing and balance. 

Special somatic afferent fibers (SSA) carry information from the special senses of vision, smell, hearing, and balance. Vestibulocochlear nerve, olfactory nerve, and optic nerve have special somatic afferent components.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

questions.text: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric regulator. Which of the following is true about fructose-2,6-bisphosphate?

choices.text: Formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-1
Fall in fructose-2,6-bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
Option C is the correct statement. A fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis.

This is a bifunctional enzyme and has the activity of both phosphofructokinase-II (PFK II) and fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase. 

  • PFK-II converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-2,6-bisphosphate. 
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase converts fructose-2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate. 

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate allosterically activates PFK-I, which is involved in converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate in glycolysis. In the well-fed state, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate acts as an intracellular signal that indicates that glucose is abundant, thereby causing an increase in the rate of glycolysis. 

In contrast, during fasting, there is the phosphorylation of this tandem enzyme by glucagon. This phosphorylation causes the inactivation of the PFK-II part and activation of the fructose-2,6-bis-phosphatase component. This results in a fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels, which favors gluconeogenesis.  

Other options:

Option A: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is formed by the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-2.

Option B: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is the most potent positive allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase-1.

Option D: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an inhibitor of fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.

questions.text: Surgical consultation is planned for a neonate in the neonatal intensive care unit. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. 

As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  • Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  • Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus and hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

Cleft-lip repair techniques:

  • Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common)
  • Thompson
  • Le Mesurier
  • Tennison–Randall

Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following:

  • Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair 
  • Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with mucosal bleeding. Laboratory investigsation revealed the cause to be due to von Willebrand disease(VWD). Which of the following subtype is the most common type of VWD?
questions.solution:
Type 1 VWD is the most common type, accounting for 60-80% of all VWD patients.

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, caused by a defect in or deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF).

Characteristics of the subtypes of VWD are summarized below:

Type Mechanism Important characteristics
1 Partial, quantitative deficiency of VWF Most common type
3 Complete quantitative deficiency Most severe VWD
2A Loss of VWF multimers (increased cleavage by ADAMS13) Platelet adhesion defect
2B Increased binding of VWF to platelets causing VWF-platelet complex destruction Thrombocytopenia
2M Decreased affinity of VWF to platelets Platelet adhesion defect, very rare
2N Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Excessive bleeding at the time of surgery

AD: autosomal dominant

AR: autosomal recessive

Common laboratory tests include:

  • WF: Ag which measures the total amount of VWF protein present
  • VWF activity test using the ristocetin cofactor activity assay (VWF: RCo), which provides a measure of the amount of functional VWF.
  • FVIII activity test

Type 1 VWD patients are treated with desmopressin and types 2 and 3 VWD are treated using VWF-containing concentrates(similar to the treatment of haemophilia)

questions.text: A patient comes with a dirty and lacerated wound. He had received a full course of tetanus vaccination previously and his last dose was about 4 years ago. Which of the following does he require?

choices.text: Single shot of tetanus toxoid vaccine

questions.solution:
A patient with a dirty and lacerated wound who completed a full course of tetanus vaccination 4 years back comes under category A.

As the patient has completed his full course of tetanus vaccination and the previous shot was within 5 years, no additional action is needed. Only wound care has to be done.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with complaints of dizziness. On examination, pallor was present. She will be considered severely anemic if her hemoglobin is less than _____.
questions.solution:
Severe anemia is defined as Hb < 7 g/dL.

Anemia in pregnancy is said to occur when Hb level is <11 g/dL. It is classified as shown below:

questions.text: A recently conceived female is curious to know the amount of weight gain that would be normal during pregnancy. Her body mass index before conceiving was 17. What is the weight gain bracket for her?
questions.solution:
As her BMI is 17, she is expected to gain weight of around 12.5 to 18 kgs.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient who was admitted to the hospital for leukemia with fever develops diarrhea after the administration of ampicillin antibiotic. Which of the following type of motility is exhibited by the most common causative agent responsible for diarrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Clostridium difficile induced diarrhoea. Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of healthcare-associated diarrhoea. It shows Stately motility.

  • All clostridia are motile, with peritrichate flagella, except C. perfringens and Clostridium tetani type VI which are non-motile.
  • Motility is slow and has been described as 'stately'.
  • Clostridium difficile induced diarrhoea usually occurs following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin or fluoroquinolones to which the organism is resistant.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes

Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum

questions.text: In adolescent breast development, which stage comes after the breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound _______
questions.solution:
The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound in stage B2, Thelarche. So, the next stage would be B3.

The development of mature breast is divided into five stages:

  • B1: Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage, only the papilla is elevated
  • B2: Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound
  • B3: There is a further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours.
  • B4: Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to the formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast.
  • B5: Formation of the mature adult breast.

questions.text: The following capnograph is obtained from an intubated patient undergoing surgery. All of the following are correct regarding the intraoperative management of this condition except?
questions.solution:
The image in the given question shows a capnograph with a sudden and progressive increase in ETCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. Dantrolene sodium is the mainstay of therapy for malignant hyperthermia but it is to be reconstituted with sterile distilled water, not saline as it can precipitate in saline or other salt solutions.

It is given at a dose of 2.5 mg/kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes (upto 10 mg/kg)  till the attack subsides.

Other options :

  • All anesthetic agents should be cut off.
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2.
  • Bicarbonate at a dose of 1 to 4 mEq/kg IV can be used to treat metabolic acidosis.
  • If the body temperature is high, it should be brought down using cold intravenous fluids, cooling body cavities with sterile iced fluids, surface cooling with ice packs and cooling blankets.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in an Indian setting?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation in India is cytomegalovirus(CMV). Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), Herpes, and varicella are also known to cause infection post-solid organ transplantation but to a lesser extent.

CMV disease in recipients can present with fever, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, malaise, and arthralgias. The diagnosis of CMV infection is established by nucleic acid testing (NAT) using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

Management of this includes use of anti-viral drugs like ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet, cidofovir and intravenous immunoglobulins.

questions.text: The gross motor milestone attained by the child shown in the below image will correspond to the age of:
questions.solution:
The image shows a child standing with support. This motor milestone is attained at around 9-10 months of age.

questions.text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: A gastrointestinal smooth muscle was being studied. It was then subjected to electrical and mechanical recording. A trace of the recordings obtained is given below. What is the effect of acetylcholine and epinephrine on the number of spikes, respectively?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine increases and epinephrine decreases the number of spikes and the tension of the gastrointestinal smooth muscle.

The smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract have a basal electrical rhythm. The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65 mV and -45 mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text: A student, soon after finishing his final year in college, joins a fitness centre and starts eating raw eggs for protein. He started developing fatigue on moderate exercise. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
The consumption of raw egg white induces symptoms of biotin deficiency.

Raw egg white contains a glycoprotein known as avidin, which tightly binds to biotin and renders it unabsorbable from the intestine. Hence, there can be a biotin deficiency state.

Biotin deficiency may cause:

  • Dermatitis
  • Mental status changes (depression, hallucinations)
  • Hyperesthesia
  • Atrophic glossitis

In infants, biotin deficiency presents as hypotonia, lethargy, and apathy. In addition, infants may develop alopecia and a characteristic rash that includes the ears.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady with a history of RTA presents with pain in the right hip. On radiological examination, fracture of the femoral head is noted with fracture line passing superior to fovea. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As the fracture line is superior to the fovea. It belongs to Pipkin’s type 2 fracture.

Pipkin’s classification is for posterior dislocation of the hip with fracture of the femoral head.

  • Type I: The fracture line is inferior to the fovea
  • Type II: The fracture line is superior to the fovea
  • Type III: Type I or II with an associated femoral neck fracture
  • Type IV: Any pattern of femoral head fracture and an acetabular fracture.

questions.text: A person is being exposed to different grades of temperature. In which of the following thermal grades will he experience the sensation of pain?
questions.solution:
The person experiences the sensation of pain in both freezing cold and burning hot temperature.

Thermal gradations are differentiated by three types of sensory receptors - cold receptors, warmth receptors, and pain receptors. The receptors are located in different areas and are differently concentrated.

In very cold temperatures, only the cold-pain fibers are stimulated. As the temperature rises to +10°C to 15°C, the cold-pain impulses cease, but the cold receptors begin to be stimulated, reaching peak stimulation at about 24°C and fading out slightly above 40°C.

Above about 30°C, the warmth receptor begins to be stimulated, but these also fade out at about 49°C. Finally, at around 45°C, the heat-pain fibers begin to be stimulated by heat.

This is the reason, why extreme degrees of both cold and heat can be painful.

The below image shows the effects of different temperatures.

questions.text: You are monitoring the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 34-year-old G2P1 woman with a term pregnancy. How long should they last for you to classify them as moderate?
questions.solution:
Moderate uterine contractions last for 20–40 s.

Weak contractions last for <20 s and strong contractions are >40 s.

During active labour, uterine contractions are 5 min apart for 1 hour, i.e., ≥ 12 contractions in 1 hour. This is accompanied by cervical dilatation of ≥3–5 cm.

questions.text: Some people underwent general health checkups at your hospital. This included a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and a range of biochemical tests on blood and urine specimens. This type of screening is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given scenario of annual health check-ups would be an example of multiphasic screening.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination at one time to a large number of people instead of screening separately for individual diseases.

This procedure includes a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and investigations that can be performed rapidly with the appropriate staffing organization and equipment. 

Other options 

Options A and C-  High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. For example, MRI screening of breast is done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in the first-degree relative.

Option D- Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-rays for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A young male patient came to the hospital with complaints of right-sided loin pain. The urine microscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is used in the treatment of these renal calculi?
questions.solution:
Urinary microscopy of the patient shows hexagonal crystals, which are suggestive of cystine stones. D-penicillamine can be used for treating cystine stones.

The basis of using D-penicillamine here is that it reacts with cystine to form a soluble salt that reduces the formation of cystine. It is a potentially toxic drug and should only be used if hydration and alkalinization fail.

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid may be considered for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor. Urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine and favoring the production of triple phosphate stones. However, it has to be used with caution due to the potential side effects.

Option B: Neutral orthophosphates halt the growth of existing oxalate calculi.

Option C: Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to decrease uric acid production. Hence, it can be used in the treatment of uric acid renal calculi.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest and most common symptom in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common and earliest symptom in carcinoma rectum patients is the passage of fresh blood in or with stools.

Other symptoms include tenesmus, mucoid discharge, and altered bowel habits. The bleeding is usually bright red in colour and painless. It can be indistinguishable from haemorrhoidal bleeding, which is the most common differential diagnosis, particularly in younger patients.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  • Bleeding
  • Mucus drainage
  • Tenesmus
  • Early morning diarrhoea
  • Pain
  • Weight loss

Modified Duke’s staging for rectal carcinoma:

A

Growth limited up to the rectal mucosa

B

B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and lymph node metastasis.

D

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A patient has complete paralysis of his right upper and lower limbs associated with ptosis and diplopia in his left eye. Which of the following vessels is involved in this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition described in the given scenario is Weber syndrome. It is caused due to an occlusion in the P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery marked as 'C' in the figure

The following image shows the different vessels contributing to the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient came to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain in the right side of lips, gums, and cheek. It occurs during both day and night and lasts for 2-3 min and has been present for 3 weeks. What is the primary agent in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms are suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. If carbamazepine is not effective then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. 

Trigeminal neuralgia is more common in women over 50 years of age. It is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory. Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis. Unilateral trigeminal nerve compresion can be due to superior cerebellar artey.

The pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief. This occurs spontaneously or is triggered by touch, cold wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). There are no objective signs of sensory loss.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with a chronic history of smoking is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. The tumour is located centrally and CT-guided biopsy reveals the following histopathology. Which of the following is not a marker of this type of carcinoma?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung. Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.P40 is a marker of squamous cell carcinoma

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

Related Pearl: Types of lung cancer

Features Adeno-carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Small cell carcinoma
Association with smoking Present, but most common type of lung cancer in non smokers Strong Strongest association
Common genetic alterations EGFR and TP53 TP53,  CDKN2A RB, TP53, MYC
Location Peripheral Central/hilar Anywhere
Precursor lesions Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia, Adeno-carcinoma in situ Squamous dysplasia, Carcinoma in situ None
Histology

Glandular differentiation, mucin production, Lepidic growth pattern

 Keratinization, squamous pearls, intercellular bridges Small cells, scant cytoplasm, salt and pepper chromatin, Azzopardi effect
IHC Mucin, TTF-1, Napsin-A p40, p63

Chromogranin, Synaptophysin, and CD56

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks. Her BP is 170/110 mm Hg and her urine dipstick is 3+. She has a generalized seizure during the examination. Her airway is secured and now, what will be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give a 4 g bolus of MgSO4 by slow IV injection
Give a 10 mg bolus IV injection of hydralazine

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia, where the first step of treatment is the establishment of the airway followed by oxygen inhalation.

The standard procedure for a patient with eclampsia is:

  • Call for extra help (communication)
  • Place the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-breather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Foley catheter with a urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 > 95%)
  • Control of seizures - MgSO4, (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension - labetalol, hydralazine
  • Fluids - crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Suction - oropharyngeal
  • Diuretics - pulmonary edema
  • Investigations to organize -
    • Blood - CBC, AST, ALT, LDH, creatinine, uric acid
    • Urine analysis - protein

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minutes followed by 
10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: Which of the following health program management method is not based on quantitative methods?
questions.solution:
Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences. In this, objectives are set forth in different units and subunits, each of which prepares its own plan of action -usually on a short-term basis.

The other options are quantitative methods.

Quantitative methods are derived from the field of economics, operation research, and budgeting.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Methods based on behavioral sciences

Quantitative methods

Organisational design

Personnel management

Communication

Information systems

Management by objectives(MBO)

Cost–Benefit analysis

Cost-Effective analysis

Cost–Accounting

Input–Output analysis

Model

Systems analysis

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was taking treatment for leprosy for the past 6 weeks. She now comes with exfoliative dermatitis associated with fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Dapsone syndrome, which is occasionally seen in leprosy patients taking dapsone.

DDS syndrome (Dapsone Syndrome) is a rarely seen side effect of dapsone therapy in leprosy patients. It starts after 6 weeks of starting dapsone and leads to exfoliative dermatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever, and hepatitis and may be fatal.

Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The uses of dapsone are:

  • Infections
    • Leprosy
    • Pneumocystis jiroveci infections
    • Malaria
    • Toxoplasma gondi infections (prophylaxis)
  • Inflammatory conditions
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Pemphigoid
    • Relapsing chondritis
    • Linear IgA bullous disease

questions.text: A young man with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. During treatment, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. His blood picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

Drugs that carry a risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

Drugs

Antimalarials
  • Primaquine
  • Chloroquine
  • Dapsone/chlorproguanil

Sulphonamides/

sulphones
  • Sulfamethoxazole
  • Sulfasalazine
  • Sulfisoxazole

Antibacterial/

antibiotics
  • Cotrimoxazole
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Nalidixic acid
  • Norfloxacin
  • Nitrofurantoin

Others
  • Naphthalene
  • Methylene blue
  • Rasburicase

questions.text: All of the following acts as water-soluble radical trapping antioxidants except:
questions.solution:
Carotenes acts as lipid-soluble radical trapping antioxidants.

Water-soluble radical- trapping antioxidants:

  • Ascorbate
  • Uric acid
  • Polyphenols, derived from plant foods

Lipid-soluble radical trapping antioxidants:

  • Ubiquinone 
  • Carotenes

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with a two-week history of gradually worsening sharp and stabbing left eye pain with redness. The severe pain kept her awakened during the night. On investigation, B-scan ultrasound shows the 'T' sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of severe worsening eye pain with redness and a B-scan showing T sign due to fluid accumulation in sub-tenon space is suggestive of posterior scleritis.

Posterior scleritis is the inflammation involving the sclera behind the equator. Ultrasonography in posterior scleritis may show the following:

  • Increased scleral thickness
  • Scleral nodules
  • Separation of tenon capsule from the sclera
  • Disc oedema
  • Choroidal folds
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fluid in the sub-tenon space may give a characteristic "T" sign. The stem of the "T" is formed by the optic nerve and the cross-bar by the fluid-containing gap. 

The image given below shows a B-scan ocular ultrasound of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from urogenital sinus?

choices.text: The upper part of the Uterus
The lower part of the Uterus
The upper part of the Vagina
The lower part of the Vagina

questions.solution:
Lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus

  • The upper part is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from _________
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows the typical bi-convex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery.

As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The thin squamous temporal bone is the common site of injury. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Note:

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Parietal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone

The pterion is an important landmark because it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following is not a protein-misfolding disease?
questions.solution:
Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is not a protein misfolding disease.

Ehlers–Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders resulting in mobile joints and skin abnormalities.  It is due to mutation in the genes encoding α collagen 1, procollagen N-peptidase and lysyl hydroxylase. 

The following are examples of protein misfolding diseases:

  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease, bovine spongiform encephalopathy, scrapie disease of sheep.
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Beta thalassemia

questions.text: The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease (stage 5) should ideally be:
questions.solution:
The renal feed of a patient suffering from end-stage renal disease should ideally be low volume, high calories.

Dietary factors may have an effect on the progression of kidney disease and its complications. A low-volume feed is preferred in order to avoid:

  • Sodium and volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites of protein degradation

A high-calorie feed is preferred in order to combat the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting seen in ESRD.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was diagnosed with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Which of the following is not a component of the triad seen in this syndrome?

choices.text: EEG showing 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves

questions.solution:
Recurrent Infections is not a component of the triad seen in a child with Lennox Gastaut syndrome.

Lennox–Gastaut syndrome typically starts between the age of 2 -10 years. It is associated with de novo mutations, perinatal hypoxia, and trauma. It consists of a triad of

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types such as atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures
  • EEG findings such as 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

The seizures can result in frequent falls and injuries. Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. Clobazam or valproate can be used for drop attacks. In resistant cases, a ketogenic diet, corticosteroids, and intravenous immunoglobulin can be tried.

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

Type of seizure  1st-line antiepileptic drugs

Focal seizures 
  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine 
  • Lamotrigine
  • Levetiracetam
  • Phenytoin
GTCS 
  • Sodium valproate
  • Levetiracetam 
  • Lamotrigine 
Typical absence seizures 
  • Ethosuximide (drug of choice)
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine
Atypical absence seizures
  • Sodium valproate 
Myoclonic seizures
  • Sodium valproate (drug of choice)
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is unemployed because he is unable to walk, as he lost his foot in an accident. The fact that he 'cannot walk' is described as _______
questions.solution:
The fact that he cannot walk is explained by the disability, according to the concept given below.

Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap

  • Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.
  • Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
  • Handicap is experiencing disadvantages due to disability and inability to discharge obligations normally.

In the given example:

  • Accident: Disease (or disorder)
  • Loss of foot: Impairment (extrinsic or intrinsic)
  • Cannot walk: Disability (objectified)
  • Unemployed: Handicap (socialized)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with pain and stiffness of the right hip.  Ultrasonography revealed effusion in the right hip joint. At which position of hip joint will the pain be minimal?
questions.solution:
A patient with an effusion in the hip joint is has least pain in flexed and abducted position.

Joint capacity is maximal when the hip joint is held in a partially flexed and abducted position. Hence, a patient with an effusion in the hip joint is therefore most comfortable in this position.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man who is a known hypertensive comes to the hospital with an altered sensorium. His blood pressure is found to be 190/110. CT scan revealed an intraparenchymal haemorrhage. 
What is the commonest site for this haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of hypertensive haemorrhage. The most common site (50-60%)of hypertensive haemorrhage in the brain is the putamen.

Hypertension is the risk factor most commonly associated with deep brain parenchymal haemorrhages. The haemorrhages are typically located in the deep white matter or deep gray structures followed by the brainstem and cerebellum.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases occur due to a chromosomal translocation?
questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma is caused by chromosomal translocation.

Chromosomal translocation refers to the phenomenon where a portion of the chromosome is split off and joined to another. This is also seen in Chronic myeloid leukemia due to Philadelphia chromosome.

Option A: Friedrich ataxia occurs due to a trinucleotide repeat expansion.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis occurs due to gene deletion.

Option D:  Sickle cell disease occurs due to a point mutation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless ulcer on his penis. A Wasserman test is done and is reactive. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Wassermann's reaction is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a non-specific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. 

An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).

questions.text: A cardiologist would make a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation for which of the following patients?

choices.text: A 40 year old hyperthyroid female with atrial fibrillation persisting for about 14 months
A 30 year old male with no cardiovascular ailment having atrial fibrillation since last month
A 45 year old hypertensive male with atrial fibrillation that resolved in 15 days
A 52 year old female with spontaneous atrial fibrillation that resolved in 5 days

questions.solution:
Atrial fibrillation that starts spontaneously and terminates within 7 days is termed paroxysmal AF. As per this definition, the 52-year-old female with spontaneous atrial fibrillation that resolved in 5 days fits into this diagnosis.

Other classifications of atrial fibrillation are

  • Persistent atrial fibrillation - AF that persists for more than 7 days.
  • Longstanding persistant atrial fibrillation  - AF that persists for more than a year.
  • Permanent atrial fibrillation - Longstanding AF that is refractory to cardioversion.
  • Lone atrial fibrillation - AF that occurs in patients younger than 60 years who do not have hypertension or any evidence of structural heart disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to ophthalmology OPD with the complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and photopsia. The consultant on duty uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. All of the following are the advantages of this instrument except  ______

choices.text: Visualization through hazy media is possible
Produces real image with 15 times higher magnification
Field of view is much larger
Depth perception of the lesion is possible

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and it produces an inverted real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.
  • Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.
  • Visualization of fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with direct ophthalmoscope.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present

Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Best diagnostic test for unilateral stress fracture is _______
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic test for a unilateral stress fracture is MRI.

For stress fracture, Best diagnostic test for,

  • Unilateral stress fracture– MRI
  • Bilateral stress fracture- Bone scan

If unilateral or bilateral is not mentioned then MRI is the preferred choice.

questions.text: The most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation uses the reagent ____________
questions.solution:
The most commonly used quantitative test for measuring the fetal red cells in the maternal circulation is the Kleihauer–Betke test and the reagent used for the Kleihauer–Betke test is citric acid. It is also known as the acid elution test.

Principle:

Fetal erythrocytes contain hemoglobin F, which is more resistant to acid elution than hemoglobin A.

After exposure to acid, only fetal hemoglobin remains, such that after staining, the fetal erythrocytes appear red and adult cells appear as “ghosts.”

Fetal cells are counted and expressed as a percentage of adult cells.

Fetomaternal hemorrhage can also be quantified using flow cytometry to measure red cell size. It is unaffected by maternal levels of fetal hemoglobin F or by fetal levels of hemoglobin A. Flow cytometry has been reported to be more sensitive and accurate than the Kleihaeur Betke test.

questions.text: Absorption of iron is increased by all of the following except ______
questions.solution:
Absorption of iron is increased by ascorbic acid. It is decreased by phosphates, oxalates, and tannates.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A drug that acts as a rheologic modifier and is hence used in the treatment of lower limb claudication is __________
questions.solution:
Pentoxifylline is a rheologic modifier used in the treatment of lower limb claudication.

It is a methylxanthine derivative and it increases the deformability of red blood cells hence called a rheologic modifier.

Other uses of pentoxifylline are:

  • Prevention of atherosclerosis
  • Prevention of cardiovascular events like acute coronary syndromes
  • Control of stable angina
  • Prevention of stroke and transient ischaemic attacks
  • Treatment of acute ischaemic stroke
  • Slowing of progression of vascular dementia
  • Preservation of tissues after thrombolytic therapy
  • Decreased inflammation and tissue damage following cardiopulmonary bypass
  • Improved outcomes in congestive heart failure
  • Improved diabetic control

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

PDE inhibitors Drugs Clinical application

Non-selective PDE inhibitors

 

Methylated xanthines, Caffeine, Theophylline

Asthma, COPD
 

Pentoxifylline

Peripheral artery disease  
PDE 2 inhibitor

Cilostazol

PDE 4 inhibitor

Roflumilast
