questions.text:
A 60-year-old male complains of shortness of breath on exertion, associated with dry cough for the past 2 months. Examination reveals grade 3 clubbing and basal rales on auscultation. HRCT of the chest shows bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma. Which of the following flow-volume loops is expected to be seen in this patient?

High-Resolution Computed Tomogram - HRCT
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an interstitial lung disease probably idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The flow-volume loop, in this case, would be similar to that of image 4 which corresponds to a restrictive pattern of the flow-volume loop.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in the fifth or sixth decade of life. Males are affected more than females. Clinical features include progressive dyspnoea more common with exertion, dry cough, and end-inspiratory crackles or rales on auscultation. Digital clubbing is seen. The HRCT findings include bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma.

The following image shows flow-volume loops in different pathological conditions-

Related Pearl: Flow-volume graph/Loop

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: 'Traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society' are called as __________
questions.solution:
Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by society.

Other options:

  • Culture is the learned behavior that is socially acquired. It is passed onto generations through formal and informal learning. Culture is the representation of customs, beliefs, laws, arts, and moral values of a society. Cultural factors have a large part to play in health.
  • Acculturation means "culture contact".There is diffusion of culture when there is contact between two people with different types of culture.
  • The role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is brought with 2nd degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the BSA involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
19% of the body surface area (BSA) is involved in this patient. The anterior part of each lower limb, according to Wallace’s rule of 9, would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA.

Rule of nines (Wallace): It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in a pediatric burn injury.

Note: Although Wallace’s rule of nines is more commonly used, the Lund and Browder chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected in children and overall.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: The area marked as " D"in the image of left kidney is related to:
questions.solution:
The area marked as " D" in the image of the left kidney is related to the jejunum.

The anterior relations of the kidneys to the abdominals structures are :

questions.text: A child with congenital thrombocytopenia presents with eczema and recurrent infections. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the WASP gene. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

choices.text: It is an X-linked recessive disorder
High levels of IgM are found in the serum
The definitive treatment is stem cell transplantation
There is an increased risk of lymphoreticular malignancies

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. Here, serum IgM levels are low, but IgG levels are usually normal, and these are associated with increased levels of IgA and IgE.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked recessive immunodeficiency. The WASP gene on Xp11.23 encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein, which plays a crucial role in cytoskeletal organization in lymphocytes and platelets. This primarily affects platelets, lymphocytes, and the immune system, leading to:

  • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count with small-sized platelets).
  • Eczema, often resembling atopic dermatitis.
  • Recurrent infections due to both B-cell and T-cell dysfunction.

Immunoglobulin abnormalities in WAS (due to T-cell dysfunction leading to defective B-cell activation and class switching, impairing IgM production while allowing IgA and IgE to be upregulated) include:

  • Low IgM results from defective B-cell signaling and impaired class switching.
  • Normal IgG levels.
  • Elevated IgA and IgE levels contribute to the eczema and allergic diathesis seen in these patients.

These abnormalities increase the patient's susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections, such as S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis. They also increase the risk of lymphoreticular malignancies. 

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the only definitive management of this condition. Supportive care includes IVIG therapy, prophylactic antibiotics, and platelet transfusions in severe thrombocytopenia. 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A known IV drug abuser is referred to medicine OPD from the de-addiction wing due to prolonged fever and new-onset seizures. His fever has been present for 2 weeks and did not come down with antibiotics. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands. What are these lesions?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of infective endocarditis. The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's nodes. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Osler nodes & Janeway lesions share similar pathogenesis, arises from micro-emboli embedding in different anatomical sites. Pain from Osler nodes is associated with emboli lodging in the glomus apparatus of the dermis. Histologically, both lesions show septic micro-emboli with dermal micro-abscess formation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male had a history of left ear discharge for the past 4 weeks and has not completed the treatment course for the same. He now has a fever with rigors.  Clinical examination shows a swollen mastoid. A CECT of the head shows the delta sign. Which of the following should not be offered as a treatment option in this case?
questions.solution:
Ligation of the internal jugular vein can be used as a treatment option for the given clinical scenario (and not ligation of the external jugular vein, which is given in option) of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is indicated only when antibiotic and surgical treatment have failed to control embolic phenomenon and rigors, or tenderness and swelling along the jugular vein.

Delta sign on CECT in a patient with ear discharge for 4 weeks, incomplete treatment, and presenting with fever and chills along with a swollen mastoid is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis, masked mastoiditis or chronic suppuration of middle ear and cholesteatoma.

It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

Clinical features:

  • Hectic Picket- Fence type of fever with rigours. 
  • Headache
  • Griesinger’s sign- This is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Oedema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
  • Papilloedema
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein (seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein). 

Investigations:

  • Blood culture to find out causative organisms.
  • CSF analysis is normal except increased CSF pressure and helps rule out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of the internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: An anatomy resident while observing the histological section of the thymus under high magnification identifies the following structure in the medullary area of the thymus. These structures are derived from which pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
The magnified view of the histology slide shows the Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) which are seen in the medullary area of the thymus. They are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch.

Hassall’s corpuscles are small rounded structures formed from whorls of medullary epithelial cells with a central partially keratinized core appearing as eosinophilic staining mass.

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the thymus in the ventral part and the inferior parathyroid gland in the dorsal part. The thymus then moves away from the pharyngeal wall in a caudal and medial direction, pulling the inferior parathyroid with it. It reaches the anterior part of the thorax, where it fuses with its counterpart from the opposite side.

The endodermal cells of the thymus get invaded by the vascular mesoderm, which contains numerous lymphoblasts. Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the endoderm of the 3rd pouch.

The following image describes the derivatives of the pharyngeal pouches.

 

Other options:

Option A - First pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the middle ear cavity and eustachian tube.

Option B - Second pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa.

Option D - Fourth pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the superior parathyroid gland, ultimobranchial body which then develop into the parafollicular "C" cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with a choledochocele. As per Todani's classification, this would be classified under which of the following types of choledochal cysts?
questions.solution:
Choledochocele is classified as type III choledochal cyst as per Todani's classification. Type III cysts have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the common bile duct (CBD).

Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the common bile duct (CBD). They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass and abdominal pain.

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts as follows:

  • Type I- is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II- it is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD, and joined to the CBD by a narrow stalk.
  • Type III- they have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the CBD and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA- the cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB- these choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease)- it consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: At which stage of a woman's life, is the vaginal pH at its maximum?
questions.solution:
The vaginal pH is maximum at post-menopausal age. The pH is more than 7.

The pH of the vagina is acidic due to the presence of lactic acid. This is mainly due to the Doderlein bacteria or lactobacillus, a large gram-positive rod. It converts the glycogen in the vaginal epithelium to lactic acid under the influence of estrogen.

The pH of the vagina is around 4.5 during the reproductive life. The acidity falls after menopause. The pH of 6-7.5 is strongly suggestive of menopause. 

The pH is also high before puberty. It is about 7.

questions.text: Which of the following remains unaffected in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The respiratory rate remains unaffected during pregnancy.

Changes in respiratory physiology occurring during pregnancy:

Parameters that increase:

  • Tidal volume
  • Inspiratory capacity
  • Minute ventilation

Parameters that decrease:

  • Functional residual capacity
  • Expiratory reserve volume
  • Residual volume
  • Total lung capacity

Parameters that remain unaffected:

  • Respiratory rate
  • Vital capacity
  • Inspiratory reserve volume

Functional residual capacity and residual volume decrease progressively during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm. Airway conductance is increased and total pulmonary resistance reduced, possibly as a result of progesterone.

(Mnemonic: TIM increases in pregnancy)

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis now presents with weakness and loss of the bulk of thenar muscles and was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following structure is spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
Radial nerve is spared in carpal tunnel syndrome as it is not a content of carpal tunnel. 

10 structures pass through the carpal tunnel, most of which are flexor tendons (not the muscles themselves).

Carpal tunnel contents (10 structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are counted as 2 structures. 

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons).
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons).
  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon).
  • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS.

Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs due to the entrapment or compression of the median nerve as it traverses underneath the carpal tunnel to enter into the wrist. Patients usually present with pain associated with tingling and numbness involving the thumb, index and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger. The little finger is usually spared as it is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Tinel's sign and Phalen's test are seen on examining patients with carpal tunnel syndrome. A late sign of carpal tunnel syndrome is thenar atrophy as seen in this patient. 

Some conditions associated with carpal tunnel syndrome include the third trimester of pregnancy, people with repetitive trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, and cysts from the carpal joints. 

Management involves measures to remove any repetitive insults that cause symptoms, wrist splinting, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, steroid injection, etc. Surgical decompression is usually indicated in patients that do not improve.

Note: Ulnar nerve passes superficial to carpal tunnel

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: A 15-year-old male has complaints of long-standing diarrhoea and weight loss. Further evaluation shows an abnormal D-xylose test and the presence of anti endomysial antibodies in him. Which of the following is an unlikely mechanism of diarrhoea in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of celiac disease, as evidenced by the presence of anti endomysial antibody. Persistent activation of adenylate cyclase is not a mechanism contributing to diarrhoea in celiac disease.

Persistent activation of adenylate cyclase which results in increased intracellular concentration of cAMP is the mechanism responsible for secretory diarrhoea in cholera infection.

The following pathogenic mechanisms contribute to diarrhoea in celiac disease

  • Steatorrhoea due to the changes in jejunal mucosal function
  • Secondary lactase deficiency, a consequence of changes in jejunal brush border enzymatic function
  • Bile-acid induced fluid secretion in the colon
  • Endogenous fluid secretion resulting from crypt hyperplasia

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked as 'X' in the following image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'X' is the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It supplies posterior cricoarytenoid muscle which is an intrinsic muscle of the larynx. All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

The cervical part of sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. Sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Stylopharyngeus is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

Option C: Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Option D: Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: A researcher during a study notices that, when a person consumes food, the stomach was able to accommodate the food with no or minor increase in pressure. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The mechanism responsible for the given process is receptive relaxation.

Receptive relaxation is a process in which the gastric fundus is dilated with the passage of food into the pharynx and esophagus. The reflex is vagally mediated.

It is a wave of relaxation transmitted through myenteric inhibitory neurons to the entire stomach and duodenum. This helps in accommodating the food reaching the stomach from the esophagus. 

Other options:

Option A: Gastroileal reflex is a vasovagal reflex wherein relaxation of the caecum occurs when the food leaves the stomach and there is increased passage of chyme through the ileocecal valve. 

Option C: Segmentation contraction is a pattern in the contraction of the small intestines that promotes the mixing of the food with intestinal secretions. In this phenomenon, the small intestine contracts at irregularly spaced intervals resulting in a chain of sausages-like appearance. When one set of contractions subsides, a new set of contractions begins at different sites.

Option D: Hunger contractions are rhythmic peristaltic contractions that occur in the body of the stomach when the stomach has been empty for a long time.

questions.text: The muscle marked as " B" in the image is ______ and is innervated by ______
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is inferior oblique and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: A 5-year-old child suffering from viral illness developed fever, for which she was given aspirin. Later the child developed Reye syndrome. The child may present with the following findings except for ______

choices.text: Liver biopsy showing inflammation or necrosis

questions.solution:
Liver biopsy in Reye syndrome reveals diffuse microvesicular fatty infiltration without any inflammation or necrosis.

Reye Syndrome : 

  • This acute encephalopathy may follow a viral upper respiratory tract infection (90% cases) or varicella infection (5-7%). 
  • History of salicylate ingestion is common.
  • Common findings include mild hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and elevated serum transaminases (>3-fold) and ammonia and coagulopathy with normal levels of serum bilirubin.
  • Liver biopsy reveals diffuse microvesicular fatty infiltration without any inflammation or necrosis.

Note : 

Aspirin and other salicylates are contraindicated in children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever because they have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. Which among the following statements is false about recording his dying declaration?

choices.text: The doctors role is to ascertain compos mentis
Dying declaration can be recorded only by the magistrate
Dying declaration has to be recorded in patient's words
Suggestions or leading questions are not allowed

questions.solution:
A dying declaration can be recorded by the doctor himself in the presence of two witnesses if he thinks that the victim will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate.

A dying declaration is a statement, verbal or written made by a victim before his or her death, relating to the circumstances leading to death. A medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded as soon as the severely injured person is brought to the hospital.

The doctors can record it themselves in the presence of two witnesses if they think that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. Treatment should not be delayed while recording a dying declaration.

The doctor has to ascertain that the dying person is of sound mind (compos mentis) before recording the statement.

If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained up to that point. It should be recorded in the patient's own words. No suggestions or leading questions are allowed, and any outsider is not allowed to be present.

After completing the writing, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it with a signature or thumb impression. The signature of two witnesses is mandatory.

questions.text: Mucocele is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are:

  • Frontal (MC)
  • Ethmoidal
  • Maxillary
  • Sphenoidal

questions.text: All of the following are premalignant lesions of invasive penile carcinoma except
questions.solution:
Of the listed conditions, Bowenoid papulosis is not a premalignant lesion.

Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brown papular lesions. It is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen disease. However, it never develops into invasive carcinoma and usually regresses spontaneously. 

Other options:

Option A: Bowen disease is a type of penile intraepithelial neoplasia that occurs on the shaft of the penis. It presents as a grey-white, opaque plaque and is associated with HPV 16. It transforms into infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in approximately 10% of patients.

Option B: Leukoplakia of glans is another type of premalignant lesion for invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the penis. It is similar to leukoplakia of the oral cavity. It is histologically characterized by hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis, with associated low-grade dysplasia. 

Option C: Erythroplasia of Queyrat is another type of penile intraepithelial neoplasia similar to Bowen disease. It presents as a red cutaneous patch on the glans penis.

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of amenorrhoea for 6 weeks and a history of prior ectopic pregnancy. Serial serum beta hCG levels were estimated in her. Which of the following findings will increase the suspicion of ectopic gestation in her?

choices.text: Low levels with prolonged doubling time
High levels with decreased doubling time

questions.solution:
Low levels of β hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy.

Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence, serial serum β hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy, the doubling time of β hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.

questions.text: A child who presents with hypotonia and seizures is diagnosed with Zellweger syndrome. All of the following findings are seen in this patient except?

choices.text: Mutation in PEX family of genes

questions.solution:
Zellweger syndrome is associated with a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

Zellweger syndrome or cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective biogenesis of peroxisomes. Mutations in the PEX (Option D) family of genes are implicated leading to a defective transport of proteins from the cytosol to the peroxisomes. This affects the metabolic pathways which are exclusive to the peroxisome such as 

  • β oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) is affected leading to the accumulation of VLCFA. (Option B)
  • α oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids (such as phytanic acid) leading to accumulation of phytanic acid.
  • Synthesis of bile acids is affected (Option C) 
  • Synthesis of plasmalogens is affected causing a marked reduction in plasmalogen levels. (Option A) 

The child presents with dysmorphic facial features like large anterior fontanelles, hypoplastic supraorbital ridges, micrognathia, and redundant nuchal skin folds. Profound developmental delay, hypotonia with depressed deep tendon reflexes, neonatal seizures, and impaired hearing are seen. Other observed abnormalities are calcific stippling of the epiphysis, renal cysts, and liver cirrhosis. There is no appropriate treatment for Zellweger syndrome. It is very severe and infants rarely survive beyond six months of age.

Other diseases of peroxisome are:

Refsum's disease results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. VLCFA levels are normal in this condition.

In X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy, the defect is an inability to transport VLCFA into the peroxisome, but other peroxisomal functions, such as α-oxidation, are normal. Elevated levels of VLCFA are seen in all tissues with normal phytanic acid levels.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: RNA produced from a fragment of DNA has the sequence of UAAGGC. The sequence of the non-template strand in the DNA that gave rise to this sequence is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
The non-template strand or coding strand in the DNA will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T is in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of UAAGGC would correspond to a DNA sequence, on the non-template strand, of TAAGGC. Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be ATTCCG (written 5′ to 3′).

questions.text: Identify the condition where dapsone is used for the treatment?
questions.solution:
Dapsone is used in the treatment of Pneumocystis jeroveci infections. Dapsone is a structural analogue of PABA and a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase in the folate pathway.

The uses of dapsone are:

  • Infections
    • Leprosy
    • Pneumocystis jeroveci infections
    • Malaria
    • Toxoplasma gondi infections (prophylxais)
  • Inflammatory conditions
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis
    • Pemphigoid
    • Relapsing chondritis
    • Linear IgA bullous disease

questions.text: What is the primary response of a bleeding vessel?
questions.solution:
The primary response of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction → platelet plug → tissue factor release → fibrin deposit.

Normal hemostasis:

  1. Arteriolar vasocontriction: After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce a transient vasoconstriction.
  2. Primary hemostasis: Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM) and are activated, undergoing a shape change and granule release. Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen, and form the primary hemostatic plug.
  3. Secondary hemostasis: Local activation of the coagulation cascade (involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids) results in fibrin polymerization, “cementing” the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  4. Clot stabilization and resorption: Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

questions.text: A 17-month-old girl presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gynecological examination showed abnormal vaginal tissue protruding through the introitus. Histopathological analysis showed sheets of spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stained positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. 

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. 
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern.

On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.

The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finance, and his health over the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following is the first-line drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms favor a diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder and the first-line drug used in this patient is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) i.e sertraline.

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) presents as excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events or activities for at least 6 months. Anxiety and worry are associated with three (or more) of the following symptoms: 

  • Restlessness
  • Being easily fatigued
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

First-line drugs for GAD are SSRIs and SNRIs. The commonly used SSRIs include sertraline, citalopram, and paroxetine, whereas, the commonly used SNRIs include venlafaxine and duloxetine. Second-line drugs include benzodiazepines, atypical antipsychotics like quetiapine, anticonvulsant like pregabalin, and other psychotropics like buspirone.

Note: It is advisable to start SSRIs along with benzodiazepines and taper benzodiazepines use after 2-3 weeks.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with cheilosis and glossitis as shown in the image. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. All of the following ocular manifestations are seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation of this patient combined with low RBC glutathione reductase activity is consistent with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency. Acute retrobulbar neuritis is not seen in riboflavin deficiency. It is a manifestation of thiamine deficiency.

Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, and inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, anemia, and personality changes.

Ocular manifestations of riboflavin deficiency,

  • Photophobia
  • Burning sensation in the eyes due to conjunctival irritation
  • vascularisation of the cornea.

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient  presented with a painful and swollen right thumb following a fall on an outstretched hand with his thumb extended. The X-ray image of his right thumb is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx. Sometimes, a small fragment of the bone may be pulled off during the injury.

Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.

Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.

Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option B: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option D: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasonographic findings is seen in a pregnant woman with dichorionic twins?
questions.solution:
Twin peak/Lambda sign is seen in dichorionic pregnancy.

The "twin peak sign" appears as a triangular projection of the chorion extending between the amnion layers. A thick dividing membrane consisting of two amnion and two chorion layers points towards the diagnosis of dichorionic pregnancy.

Note: T sign is the absence of a twin peak sign. There is a lack of chorion extending between the amnion layers and hence, suggestive of a monochorionic pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: You are a physician at a primary health center. A 2-year-old child weighing 12 kg is brought to you. He appears lethargic and is not taking food or fluids orally. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 45/min, and stridor is heard. What is the next step of management?

choices.text: Give a dose of IV chloramphenicol and urgently refer to the hospital
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.solution:
The child in this case has features of severe pneumonia with the presence of danger signs like lethargy, inability to drink, and stridor. Therefore, pre-referral treatment like the first dose of injectable chloramphenicol should be given and urgently referred to a hospital. If chloramphenicol is not available, oral amoxicillin can be given.

This is based on the revised WHO classification and treatment of childhood pneumonia at health facilities. Pneumonia with general danger signs like inability to drink, persistent vomiting, convulsions, lethargy or unconscious, stridor in a calm child, or severe malnutrition needs antibiotics with urgent referral to a higher center.

The following image shows the IMNCI Guidelines for the treatment of pneumonia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with cough, chest pain, and hoarseness of voice. On CT chest a mass is seen in the anterior mediastinum. All of the following are differential diagnoses except:
questions.solution:
Schwannoma is not found in the anterior mediastinum. It is found in the posterior mediastinum.

Teratoma, mantle cell lymphoma, and thymoma can be found in anterior mediastinum.

Neurogenic tumors are the most common primary tumors of the posterior mediastinum. Schwannomas and neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors.

Locations of various mediastinal tumors are given below:

Anterior Mediastinum

Middle Mediastinum

masses

Parathyroid adenoma

Cysts (Most common):

  • Pericardial (most common)
  • Bronchogenic
  • Enterogenous
  • Neuroenteric

LN enlargement and lymphoma

Mesenchymal tumors

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer who spends most of his time working in the rice field presented with nasal obstruction. Rhinoscopic examination revealed a pink polypoidal mass in his left nostril. Histopathologic examination showed several sporangia with a thick wall, filled with spores. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the histopathology findings are suggestive of rhinosporidiosis. Surgical management is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • Chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • Most prevalent in rural districts, among persons bathing in public ponds or working in stagnant water, such as rice fields. 
  • Most common in persons in the age range of 15–40; males are more commonly affected than females.
  • The rhinoscopic examination will reveal papular or nodular, smooth-surfaced lesions that become pedunculated and acquire a papillomatous or proliferative appearance. The lesions are pink, red or purple in colour
  • Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores.
  • The treatment of choice is surgical excision of lesions, with or without cauterization.

Note: Not many drugs are effective against this disease. Dapsone has been tried with some success.

The image below shows a polypoidal mass of Rhinosporidiosis coming out of the right nostril

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of the use of the substance called ‘baseball’?
questions.solution:
Magnan syndrome is a complication of the use of 'baseball' (cocaine).

Magnan syndrome - A type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

  • Meth mouth - Advanced tooth decay (termed “meth mouth”) is common in habitual methamphetamine users.
  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy, lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - Run-amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis, and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

Other named effects of drug use

  • Crack dancing - Choreo athetosis and repetitive movements (termed “crack dancing”) are associated with cocaine and amphetamine intoxication and appear related to dopamine dysregulation.
  • Crack eye - A syndrome of corneal abrasions and ulcerations secondary to smoke and irritation assocaited crack cocaine use is known as “crack eye.”
  • Crack baby - The term ‘crack baby’ was used to describe children who were exposed to crack as fetuses in the US.
  • Bad trip - LSD use - Profound distortions in perception of sensory stimuli, time, emotions, and memories occur and may cause users to experience paranoia, depression, extreme panic, or an acute psychotic reaction known as a dysphoric reaction or “bad trip.”
  • Flashbacks - Prolonged and sometimes permanent psychosis, known as “flashbacks” or “hallucinogen persisting perception disorder,” can result from LSD use.
  • Carphologia - Carphologia (or carphology) is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state. Usually associated with Datura poisoning.

questions.text: Which type of aquaporin is present in the portion of the nephron that is responsible for maximum reabsorption of Na +?
questions.solution:
Maximum reabsorption of Na + occurs in proximal convoluted tubules and Aquaporin 1 is present at this site in the kidney.

Despite a handful number of aquaporins present in the human body, the kidneys predominantly have the aquaporins 1, 2, 3, and 4.

Aquaporin 1 is present in the proximal convoluted tubules. It is localized to both the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules. Its presence allows water to move rapidly out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients and isotonicity is maintained. 

Aquaporin 2, which is located in the collecting duct is under the influence of the antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Interaction of ADH with V2 receptors in the basolateral membrane causes the insertion of aquaporin 2 channels in the apical membrane of the tubular cell to facilitate water reabsorption.

AQP-3 and AQP-4 are present on the basolateral side of the cell membrane, especially in the collecting ducts. They provide a path for water to rapidly exit the cells, and are not regulated by ADH.

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: The Mullerian Ducts will regress in __________________
questions.solution:
The Mullerian Ducts will regress in the presence of the Y Chromosome. The Y chromosome has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene (Sex-determining Region of the Y chromosome). If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called Testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH), a peptide hormone, that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

In absence of the Y chromosome and the SRY gene consequently, the gonads will develop as ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the fallopian tubes and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene for this is the presence of WNT4.

Thus, the fate of the Mullerian duct, whether it regresses or differentiates, is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, respectively, and not by the X chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following is called leukocyte common antigen?
questions.solution:
CD45 is called leukocyte common antigen because it is found in all leukocytes.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Antigen Designation and their Normal Cellular Distribution 
Primarily T-Cell Associated 
  • CD1 Thymocytes and Langerhans cells 
  • CD3 Thymocytes, mature T cells 
  • CD4 Helper T cells, subset of thymocytes  
  • CD5 T cells and a small subset of B cells  
  • CD8 Cytotoxic T cells, subset of thymocytes, and some NK cells 
Primarily B-Cell Associated 
  • CD10 Pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells 
  • CD19 Pre-B cells and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD20 Pre-B cells after CD19 and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD21 EBV receptor; mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD23 Activated mature B cells 
  • CD79a Marrow pre-B cells and mature B cells 
Primarily Monocyte or Macrophage Associated 
  • CD11c Granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages; also expressed by hairy cell leukemias 
  • CD13 Immature and mature monocytes and granulocytes 
  • CD14 Monocytes 
  • CD15 Granulocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants
  • CD33 Myeloid progenitors and monocytes  
  • CD64 Mature myeloid cells  
Primarily NK-CellAssociated 
  • CD16 NK cells and granulocytes  
  • CD56 NK cells and a subset of T cells 
Primarily Stem Cell and Progenitor Cell Associated  
  • CD34 Pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages 
Activation Markers 
  • CD30 Activated B cells, T cells, and monocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants 
Present on All Leukocytes 
  • CD45 All leukocytes; also known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA)

questions.text: A 70-year-old female who is on symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis for 15 years came to the hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspepsia. Endoscopy showed gastric mucosal inflammation and ulcer. Which of the following drugs is approved by the FDA for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is likely to be on NSAIDs as a symptomatic therapy for osteoarthritis. NSAIDs cause gastric ulcers by inhibiting protective action on mucosa by prostaglandins. PGE1 analogue (Misoprostol) is approved by the FDA for NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.

Prostaglandins inhibit and reduce gastric acid secretion in a dose-dependent manner. They also increase mucosal blood flow and stimulate bicarbonate and mucin secretion which contribute to its cytoprotective action.

questions.text: The following sign shown in the barium enema study is frequently seen in __________
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the barium enema study is the Apple core sign seen in Colonic cancer.

The apple core sign, also known as the napkin ring sign (bowel), is most frequently associated with constriction of the lumen of the colon by a stenosing annular colon carcinoma. 

The appearance of the apple-core lesion of the colon also can be caused by other diseases :

  • Villous adenoma
  • Lymphoma with colonic involvement
  • Crohn disease
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis
  • Ischaemic colitis
  • Chlamydia infection
  • Colonic tuberculosis
  • Helminthoma
  • Colonic amoebiasis
  • Colonic cytomegalovirus

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought for a sleep study. Polygraphic measurements show that the patient was in paradoxical sleep. All of the following is seen during this stage of sleep except ________
questions.solution:
Paradoxical sleep has also been termed REM sleep. In REM sleep there will be no increase in tidal volume.

Brain oxygen use increases during REM sleep. The ventilatory response to increased levels of carbon dioxide is depressed during REM sleep, so that no increase in tidal volume occurs as the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (Pco2) increases. 

Dreaming is associated with rapid eye movement (REM) sleep.

Other changes in REM sleep:

  • Loss of muscle tone
  • Partial or full penile erection
  • Increased heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate
  • Increased brain oxygen consumption

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a dense cataract has been posted for cataract surgery. Since fundus examination was not possible due to dense cataract, the surgeon advises getting an electrophysiological test to assess the retinal function. The record obtained is as shown below. Which of the following waves represent the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram(ERG). The metabolic activity of pigment epithelium is represented by a C wave.

Electroretinography (ERG) is the record of changes in the resting potential of the eye induced by the stimulation of a flash of light.

Waves of normal ERG

  • a-wave is a negative wave possibly representing the activity of rods and cones
  • b-wave is a large positive wave that is generated by Muller cells. They represent the activity of the bipolar cells
  • c-wave is a positive wave representing the metabolic activity of pigment epithelium

ERG is used in the diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders like retinitis pigmentosa, Leber’s congenital amaurosis, retinal ischemia, and other chorioretinal degenerations.

It helps to assess retinal function when fundus examination is not possible like in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity. It is also used to assess the retinal function of the children where possibilities of impaired vision are considered.

A subnormal B wave is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa. 

An extinguished response is seen when there is complete failure of rod and cone function in advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, and central retinal artery occlusion. 

A negative response is seen when there is gross disturbances of retinal circulation.

questions.text: Hennebert's sign is seen in ________
questions.solution:
Hennebert's sign is a positive fistula sign in the absence of a fistula seen in congenital syphilis due to formation of adhesions between stapes footplate and saccule.

This is not to be confused with Hennebert's phenomenon which is disequilibrium following nose blowing or lifting a heavy object. It is seen in perilymph fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Basement Membrane Zone?
questions.solution:
Desmosome is not a component of Basement Membrane Zone.

Basement membrane zone or dermo-epidermal junction is the junction between epidermis and dermis. This zone is composed of 3 components:

  • Hemidesmosome
  • Anchoring Filaments
  • Anchoring Fibrils.

Note: Desmosomes are the major adhesion complex in the epidermis, anchoring keratin intermediate filaments to the cell membrane and bridging adjacent keratinocytes, and allowing cells to withstand trauma.

Related Pearl: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

  • The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.
  • As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.
  • Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities
    • Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer
    • Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer
  • This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

  • Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.
  • The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.
  • The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

  • The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.
  • Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.
  • Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

  • These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.
  • Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.

Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

Image: Gene/protein systems within the cutaneous basement membrane zone that can harbour mutations and result in blistering of the skin in different forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB). BP, bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with history of squamous cell carcinoma lung presents with shortness of breath. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the golden S sign which is seen in the right upper lobe collapse.

Golden S-sign is seen on both PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in the right upper lobe collapse. It is named because this sign resembles a reverse S shape, and is therefore sometimes referred to as the reverse S-sign of Golden. 

Although typically seen with the right upper lobe collapse, the S-sign can also be seen with the collapse of other lobes. It is created by a central mass obstructing the upper lobe bronchus. It should raise suspicion of a primary bronchogenic carcinoma. It can also be caused by other central masses, such as metastasis, primary mediastinal tumor, or enlarged lymph nodes.

The additional finding in this X-ray is the presence of calcified breast implants.

questions.text: What is implied if a drug has more renal clearance than GFR?

choices.text: Drug is reabsorbed by the renal tubules
Drug is secreted in the renal tubules
Drug is excreted in renal tubules
Drug is neither excreted nor reabsorbed in renal tubules

questions.solution:
If drug has more renal clearance than GFR, then drug is secreted in renal tubules. 

Excretion rate= (filtration rate- reabsorption rate)+ secretion rate.

The clearance of the substance:

  • Equals the GFR if there is no net tubular secretion or reabsorption.
  • Exceeds the GFR if there is net tubular secretion.
  • Less than the GFR if there is net tubular reabsorption.

questions.text: The predominance of intermediate cells on vaginal cytology occurs in which phase of life?
questions.solution:
Intermediate cell predominance on vaginal cytology is seen in pregnancy.

During pregnancy, navicular cells are predominant in a cluster (small intermediate cells with elongated nuclei) and plenty of lactobacilli.

Related Pearl: Cytohormonal study of the vaginal epithelium

Layer Cell characteristics Hormones Age of the woman
Parabasal and basal Small, round and basophilic with large nuclei Lack of hormonal activity

Childhood until puberty

Menopause with atrophy
Intermediate cells

Transparent and basophilic (blue-green) with vesicular nuclei

 Progesterone, Androgen, Corticosteroid 

Pregnancy

At an early transition of  menopause
Superficial cells Large cells with a pyknotic nucleus, acidophilic on staining Estrogen

Reproductive period

Preovulatory phase

Note: Malignant cells contain less cytoplasm, and hyperchromatic nuclei which are variable in size.

questions.text: A patient on an antipsychotic pharmacotherapy started complaining of browning of vision. This is due to _________
questions.solution:
Thioridazine is associated with the browning of vision.

Pigmentary retinopathy is an adverse effect of thioridazine. In advanced cases, the deposits may resemble retinitis pigmentosa, and the deposits are associated with "Browning of Vision".

It is rarely used as it causes prolongation of QTc interval.

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation
Amisulpride Hyperprolactinemia
Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with a common congenital anomaly of the gall bladder. CT demonstrating the congenital anomaly is given below. Name the anomaly.
questions.solution:
CT scan shows an incomplete fold across the fundus representing a phrygian cap.

Phrygian cap is the most common anomaly of the gallbladder, where the fundus is folded inwards.

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary system where gallbladder structure is not obliterated.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with mild skeletal deformities and a corneal opacity. He had no signs of mental retardation. Investigations revealed L-Iduronidase enzyme deficiency. Dermatan sulfate is positive in the urine. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with L-iduronidase enzyme deficiency is suggestive of Scheie's Syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

Deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase results in a wide range of clinical involvement, from severe Hurler syndrome to mild Scheie syndrome. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

The Scheie syndrome (MPS I-S ) is a milder form of MPS-I. The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic (corneal clouding, glaucoma, and retinal degeneration) and cardiac involvement (aortic valve disease) might be present. In Scheie's Syndrome, dermatan sulfate is lost in the urine.

The Hurler syndrome (MPS I-H) is a severe progressive disorder with the involvement of multiple organs and tissues that results in premature death. Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. 

Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Related Pearl: MPS and Their Respective Enzyme Deficiencies

coarse facial features,

Motor dysfunction
