questions.text: Which stage of tuberculosis of the hip presents with apparent lengthening of the limb?
questions.solution:
In a patient with tuberculosis of the hip, apparent lengthening of the limb is seen in the stage of synovitis.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

Stage Limb length Reason
Stage of synovitis Apparent lengthening Abduction deformity
Stage of early arthritis Apparent shortening Adduction deformity
Stage of advanced arthritis True shortening Destruction of articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.
Stage of arthritis with subluxation True shortening Destruction of acetabulum leads to dislocation of the femur head


Stage of arthritis with subluxation also known as wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of the femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the umbilicus to the medial malleolus and the true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus. The apparent length is increased when there is abduction deformity of the limb and decreased when there is adduction deformity of the limb.

questions.text: Which among the following is the active principle present in the dried fruit shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are semicarpol and bhilawanol.

Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options

Option A: Calotropin is one of the active principles of Calotropis.

Option C: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius

Option D:  Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis.

questions.text: A man is arrested by the police after multiple FIRs were registered against him for rubbing his genitals against women inappropriately in public transport. On questioning, the man says that he gets sexual gratification this way. Which of the following paraphilias describes this behavior?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of frotteurism. It refers to the sexual gratification obtained by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person. 

This behavior often occurs in busy, crowded places, such as on busy streets or on crowded buses or subways. It is predominantly described in men. A frotteur may fantasize that the woman he is rubbing up against is mutually aroused by the behavior.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: The following finding was noted on the cardiac tissue specimen of an 82-year-old man. Which of the following is false about the given finding?

choices.text: It is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury
It is injurious to the cell and its function
It is derived through lipid peroxidation
It can also be seen in liver of aging patients

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows yellow-brown lipochrome or lipofuscin pigment. It is not injurious to the cell or its functions.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment derived from the peroxidation of lipids of subcellular membranes. It is an indicator of free radical injury to the cells.

It is an insoluble, brownish yellow, granular intracellular material that is seen in the liver, brain, and heart due to normal aging. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

It can also be seen in patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen over his right arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. On Gram staining from cultures, bamboo stick appearance was seen. Which of the following reactions is characteristic of this bacilli?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a necrotic ulcer with a characteristic black eschar are suggestive of cutaneous anthrax with septicemia signs caused by Bacillus anthracis. The characteristic reaction shown by these bacilli is M'Fadyean’s reaction.

When blood films containing anthrax bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue for a few seconds and examined under the microscope, amorphous purplish material is noticed around the bacilli which shows the capsular material. This is called M'Fadyean’s reaction.

Cutaneous anthrax is usually acquired by the entry of spores through injured skin. The lesion starts as a papule and becomes vesicular. Several satellite lesions are seen around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar. This lesion is called a malignant pustule. Cutaneous anthrax generally resolves spontaneously.

On microscopy, they appear as gram-positive rods. Bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains. The ends of the bacilli are truncated or often concave and somewhat swollen so that a chain of bacilli presents a bamboo stick appearance.

The organisms produce nonhemolytic grey-to-white, tenacious colonies with a rough texture and a ground-glass appearance in blood agar. Comma-shaped outgrowths (Medusa head, curled hair) may project from the colony.

Other options:

Option A - Naegler's reaction is a useful test for the rapid detection of Clostridium perfringens.

Option B - The reverse CAMP test is used to identify Clostridium perfringens.

Option D - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon is demonstrated by sporotrichosis, pityrosporum folliculitis, zygomycosis, candidiasis, aspergillosis, and blastomycosis. It is also seen in bacterial infections such as botryomycosis, nocardiosis, and actinomycosis, and parasitic conditions include orbital pythiosis, strongyloidiasis, schistosomiasis, and cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with bleeding per rectum. He gives a history of lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and return spontaneously thereafter. The degree of hemorrhoids would be:
questions.solution:
Lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and which return spontaneously afterwards indicate second degree haemorrhoids.

Four degrees of haemorrhoids:

First degree – bleed only, no prolapse

Second degree – prolapse but reduce spontaneously

Third degree – prolapse and have to be manually reduced

Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. The lesion in which of the following level will produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of glottis, subglottis (B), and cervical trachea will cause Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is undergoing focused parathyroidectomy. After removal of parathyroid adenoma, the surgeon can confirm that there are no hyperactive parathyroid tissue left if the intraoperative PTH,
questions.solution:
A drop of intraoperative PTH to <50% of the preoperative PTH in 10 minutes suggests a single-gland disease. This is known as Miami criteria.

About 80% of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text:
Which of the following arteries are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Iliolumbar artery
questions.solution:
The superior gluteal artery and iliolumbar artery are branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Superior gluteal artery
  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery
  • Superior vesical artery
  • Inferior vesical artery 
  • Inferior gluteal artery
  • Middle rectal artery
  • Vaginal artery (in females)
  • Uterine artery (in females)
  • Internal pudendal artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fever and painful enlargement of her thyroid gland. She also gives a history of having an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) 2 days ago. A biopsy of the thyroid gland showed findings as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The painful enlargement of the thyroid gland with a history of URTI and the image above showing granulomatous inflammation in the thyroid gland are suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

This condition is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, and migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition and this condition occurs due to virus-induced host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T-lymphocyte response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men. Histopathology shows the presence of granulomas in the thyroid gland.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever and examination reveals a small goiter that is very tender.

It has three distinct phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase
  • Hypothyroid phase
  • Recovery phase

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids, and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

Other options: 

Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.

Option D: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a nonpainful, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

questions.text: The PAGE DNA electrophoresis of the affected cell shows a smear pattern. Additionally, Annexin V is negative. Which of the following is a true statement about this type of cell death?

choices.text: It can be physiological or pathological

questions.solution:
The cell death discussed here is necrosis. Karyolysis is seen in necrosis.

Pyknosis followed by karyorrhexis and karyolysis is the pattern of nuclear changes observed in necrosis.

Other options:

Option A: Apoptosis is genetically programmed
Option B: Apoptosis can be physiological or pathological. Necrosis is always pathological.
Option C: Apoptosis has an intact plasma membrane. In necrosis, plasma membrane is disrupted.

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Feature

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Mechanism

Enzymatic or ischemic process

Passive process

Genetically programmed cell death

Active process
Physiologic or pathologic role

Invariably pathologic 

Both physiologic and pathologic

Cell size

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Cells affected

Group of cells

Single cell death

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to the Emergency room with acute abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting.  Immediate ultrasound was ordered and results revealed a swollen adnexal mass, globular in shape, and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is of an Ovarian Torsion. Torsion warrants immediate surgery.

This is an emergency requiring urgent laparotomy. One is advised to try and conserve the ovary if possible unless gangrene has set in.

De-torsion of the ovary and ovariopexy should be attempted.

The ovary should be observed for color change from a bluish-black appearance to its normal appearance. The theoretical risk of embolism with de-torsion does not normally occur. The ovary recovers and becomes functional. This is especially important in a young woman.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female who is a known case of sarcoidosis has the following skin lesions in her legs. Which of the following would be an effective treatment for this next to steroids?
questions.solution:
The skin lesions in the given clinical image are suggestive of erythema nodosum. It is one of the predominant cutaneous manifestations of sarcoidosis. Antimalarial drug-like hydroxychloroquine is considered a better drug next to corticosteroids in managing this.

Treatment options in sarcoidosis

  • Glucocorticoids remain the main drug of choice in the treatment of sarcoidosis.
  • In those patients who require persistent corticosteroids, the following steroid-sparing alternatives are considered 
    • Hydroxychloroquine 
    • Methotrexate
    • Azathioprine
    • Leflunomide
    • Mycophenolate
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Thalidomide to some extent in a limited number of cases

questions.text: What is the embryological precursor of the marked structure :
questions.solution:
The marked structure is ligamentum teres, and it is an embryological remnant of the left umbilical vein.
